TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Honourable H. C. Templeton, M.P., New Zealand Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Customs. On behalf of the House I extend to him a very warm welcome.

—Does the Prime Minister recall his 1975 election promise in which he said: 'We will reduce the tax burden'? He repeated this in 1977 when he said: ' The Government would bring taxes down further-not increase them'. Is it a fact that since 1975-76 the total tax payments by wage and salary earners have risen by almost 150 per cent while wages and salaries have risen by only two-thirds as much? In view of the Prime Minister's repeated promises to cut taxes, when can the great bulk of Australian men and women expect relief from the extra $1,500m in income taxes which they have had to pay this year?

—Over the last several years we have paid off the Australian Labor Party's deficit, firstly by expenditure restraint in all of our Budgets. We have exhibited greater expenditure restraint than most other governments, not just governments in Australia, and certainly much greater expenditure restraint than was exhibited between 1972 and 1975. There was none then. We have paid off that deficit by expenditure restraint and also by an approach to taxation which people understand means that as a country we have to pay our way as we go. It is also worth noting that if we were taking as much out of each dollar as Labor did we would be spending $3.7 billion more this year. We are taking 2 1/2c less out of each dollar that people produce. In the financial year 1980-81 the real household disposable income of Australian families increased by $2.9 billion after tax. On top of that of course there have been very substantial wage claims , in addition to the reduction in hours which has occurred as a result of settlements over the last six to 10 months.

The two matters raised by the honourable member, that is, daylight saving and electricity rationing, are matters which concern one quarter of a million Australians who live in the national capital. Last year, as a result of a motion passed in the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, I wrote to the New South Wales Government seeking its views with respect to a possible extension of daylight saving. The New South Wales Government, giving very little weight to the views of the quarter of a million Australians who live in Canberra , rejected out of hand the proposal which I put on behalf of the elected representatives of Canberra. I heard nothing further until February of this year when Mr Greg Turnbull of the Sydney Morning Herald informed me that the Wran Government in New South Wales had unilaterally determined that daylight saving was to be extended. —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, refers to the present crisis in the member countries of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries regarding the world glut of crude oil. I ask: Can the Minister inform the House whether the alleged glut will have an effect on oil supplies and prices in Australia? If the OPEC countries agree upon a price reduction at their meeting later this month, will any such reduction be reflected in any reviews of oil pricing made in Australia, in either July of this year or January of next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1977 Australia has had a firm and consistent policy regarding the import price of crude oil. That policy has been to adjust the price according to the price of Saudi light crude oil. That adjustment takes place every six months, on 1 January and 1 July. In making the adjustment we take into account also any freight differentials, and exchange variations that might occur . The price of Saudi oil is based on the United States dollar. Therefore, changes in the relationship between the Australian dollar and the United States dollar are taken into account. In most cases the price of imported crude oil has gone up in line with the price of Saudi oil, but a precedent was set in 1978 when the price actually came down as a result of exchange variations and other factors such as I have mentioned. In that case, the price was reduced from $13 to about $12.65 a barrel. To forecast what the changes on 1 July will be is very difficult. There will be changes because of the factors that I have mentioned.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that the Minister speak into the microphone. We on this side cannot hear him.

—I am sorry. It does appear that there will be some changes because of pressures that are being put on Saudi Arabia now to lower the price. Although nobody can predict what is going to happen, the producers are certainly cutting back on the volume of their production in order to try to tighten up on the surplus oil supply around the world. But until the end of June, and until we can take account of all of these factors, it is not possible to predict whether the price will come down, remain the same, or go up.

—Is the Treasurer aware that the major trading banks currently direct less than 6 per cent of their total lending to persons wishing to build or purchase their own home? Is it a fact that a mere 2 per cent increase in this ratio would mean that an extra $400m would be made available for lending to home buyers-enough for around 10,000 new home loans? In view of the urgent need to take action to assist home buyers and the fact that around 30 per cent of trading bank deposits are free of interest, will the Treasurer immediately use his powers under the Banking Act to introduce a housing ratio for trading banks, compelling such banks to increase the volume of their lending for housing purposes?

—I think the figure of 6 per cent is about correct. I should point out to the honourable gentleman that traditionally lending from the banking system for housing has been through savings banks and a number of the savings banks already are right on or very close to the amount that can be lent for housing under the existing housing regulations. The honourable gentleman has raised a question-I know he has done it seriously-relating to the housing issue. All aspects of that matter are under consideration by the Government at present. I have said before and I will say again that we do not propose to be stampeded into making a decision. If any changes are found to be necessary by the Government, they will be changes that are meant to last, meant to be effective and meant to tackle the basic causes of difficulties in the housing area, and not designed to be a cosmetic, unworkable solution.

However, I remind the Minister that it would be preferable not to make a direct comment upon the quality of the case of one of the parties.

—Mr Speaker, I am conscious of the point you have made. I was answering the point about the media comment that has been made on behalf of the ACTU outside the Commission. I point out that not only is there the claim for what is called a community catch-up to be based on a community wage standard but also there is a claim for a return to automatic indexation and that in particular the automatic adjustment for cost of living increases should include an adjustment for movements in the six capital consumer price indices for the quarter ending December 1981. Of course, if that were granted it would result in a significant wage increase for the whole community.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 321 and the fact that the Minister is reading from a document. In answering this question he is reading directly from a document. I ask that the document be tabled.
—Is the Minister quoting from a document?
—Mr Speaker, I was quoting directly from a copy of the claim lodged by Mr S. Crean for and on behalf of the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia.

—I take a point of order. The Minister is misleading the House. He was answering this question by reading directly from a document. He was not just quoting from the document to which he refers. He has two documents and he should not--
—The honourable gentleman has made his point. He will resume his seat . Is the Minister quoting from any document currently in his possession?

—I am quoting from the document to which I have just referred. To verify the fact, for the benefit of the honourable member for Chifley, let me quote what is in this document signed by Mr Crean. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: To introduce automatic quarterly cost of living adjustments. Such adjustment to include movements in six capital CPI for the quarter ending December 1981.
I table the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order which is in direct support of the point of order raised by the honourable member for Chifley. Unless the document on top is transparent the Minister could not have been reading from the document to which he now refers.
—Now be honest.
—The honourable member for Chifley will withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, I am in a difficult position. I withdraw.
—I can see that the Minister has another document. The honourable gentleman has already tabled one document. Was the Minister quoting from the other document?
—No.
—I ask the Minister to continue his answer.

—The second part of the honourable gentleman's question enables me to restate the position announced by me to the House the other day with regard to the Government's policy on wage determination in Australia. That is that we believe that it would be to the benefit of Australia if there were a continuation of the industry by industry approach or, as it is otherwise called, the case by case approach by which unions are enabled to make their claims before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and have their claims processed on the merits of those claims. We believe that the capacity of the economy is not sufficient to bear any significant or general wage increases over and above those which have been granted on the industry by industry approach. If that approach were allowed to continue we in Australia would have an orderly approach to wage determination based on principles well enunciated by the Arbitration Commission over many years.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of a published report that he had been advised by his Department last November that there was no economic case for adopting any policies to cope with the present housing crisis? Are these reports correct? If so, has he accepted the advice? If not, will the Prime Minister give a solemn undertaking that the world economic situation will not be used as an excuse to abandon urgently needed Commonwealth action to deal with the real social problems arising from the crisis in housing in Australia?

—The answer to the first two parts of the question is yes. I would like to make the point that the advice was economic advice. It is obvious from the report in the newspaper that having said what the Department thought was proper economic advice it went on to outline a variety of options which could be examined. I emphasise the words 'economic advice' because there are obviously social objectives, objectives for Australian families, which are not entirely economic. The honourable gentlemen has recognised that in his question. I do not think it is helpful when reports of this kind are published. But I want to make the point that I expect my Department and indeed all departments to give the advice that they believe to be right and if that happens to be something which they think Ministers may not want to hear or to accept, so be it. Ministers and governments have to make up their mind on the basis of advice and I am very grateful that my Department never fails to speak its mind on whatever issue I ask questions of it.

—I ask the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs: Will the Government continue to keep its recently announced motor vehicle policy continually under review? Will it, as a part of that review, consider putting motor vehicle import quotas to auction or tender?

—I note the interest of the honourable member for Hume on this aspect of Government industry policy. At present, in association with the Minister for Industry and Commerce, we are developing a series of regulations to put that new policy into place. The question of allocation of quotas to historical owners is one of the matters that we are considering at present. Whether the tender process is the most appropriate is something which we will have to look at. The experience in the footwear, clothing and textile industries where 85 per cent of quota was allotted to historical base and 15 per cent was put up for tender has produced some anomalies in that process. Naturally we will be looking at that experience.

—I would like to ask the Prime Minister a question. May I commence by congratulating him on his speech at lunch time and may I particularly congratulate him on his comments in relation to Cyprus which I interpreted as reflecting a warm commitment to the sovereign rights of Cyprus. I ask the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that when General Assembly resolutions in relation to this matter, specifically the sovereign rights of Cyprus, have come before the United Nations from and including 1974 to and including 1978, Australia voted in support of those resolutions? Is it a fact that on the only other occasion-the last occasion-when such a resolution came before the United Nations in 1979, Australia voted against that resolution? Will he explain in some detail the justification for the sudden departure from a well-established and justifiable endorsement of these resolutions prior to that date? Can we interpret his statement at lunch time today as a clear indication that the Government will remedy its aberrant way displayed in 1979 and henceforth support United Nations General Assembly resolutions that declare a commitment in support of the sovereign rights of Cyprus?
—I welcome the Leader of the Opposition to the ecumenical movement, and I should like to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs to answer the question.

—As I am sure the Leader of the Opposition will know, intercommunal talks are in progress in Cyprus on this question. The Secretary-General of the United Nations has interested himself in the issues being discussed. It is the Australian Government's view that these intercommunal talks offer the best prospect of an equitable and lasting settlement to the Cyprus question. They are still in progress. While we support international efforts to solve the problem - we support also the efforts of the Secretary-General of the United Nations in that respect-we still believe that so long as the intercommunal talks are continuing, they offer the best prospect of resolution.

—My honourable friend conveys to me something which is absolutely novel . I would be heavily in debt to my honourable friend if he were to give me any particulars, and I can assure him that they would be remedied immediately.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister.
—I have called two questions from the Opposition benches successively . I shall continue with the call and make it up.

—Is the Prime Minister aware that over 400 Russians, 600 Americans and many British and French scientists and their support workers are operating in the Antarctic area to which Australia lays claim? Is it also a fact that there are fewer than 80 Australians working in Antarctica and that comparitively few of them are scientists? Is it a fact that over 30 positions at the Antarctic base at Kingston cannot be filled because of razor gang staff ceilings? Finally, does the Prime Minister acknowledge that Australia's tenuous right to control 40 per cent of Antarctica rests on our scientific endeavours and that if we fail in that respect our claims will be jeopardised in the eyes of the world?

—Australia's scientific record in Antarctica is very good. Of course, our efforts cannot compare with those of the United States of America or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, but in proportion we do very well. In the summer period this year we had 130 people in our three bases on the Antarctic mainland. Twenty-nine of those were scientists.
—Twenty-nine?
—Yes. We spend about $2m on science in Antarctica each year. We have a very big drain on our resources in the rebuilding program and until that rebuilding--
—But you are not doing any science.
—Order! The honourable member for Lalor will remain silent.

—I hope that one day the honourable member for Lalor will be able to go to Antarctica. I invite him to go, provided we can fit him in the very limited transport facilities. We are rebuilding the Antarctic bases at a cost of $58m over 10 years.
—But you are not doing any science.
—The honourable member for Lalor has made that comment several times. I ask him to be silent.

—The reason I want the honourable member for Lalor to go there is to see that the accommodation available at the moment is limited. It is further limited by the fact that we are rebuilding the bases during the summer period and that means that carpenters, plumbers and electricians also have to be accommodated there. Once the rebuilding program is completed I hope we will be able to increase our scientific effort. There is no doubt that with a relatively small increase in funds we could double our scientific effort in Antarctica.
—Why don't you tell--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Lalor to remain silent.

—We have increased our efforts considerably in Antarctica in the last few years. A great deal of money has been spent in various ways and will continue to be spent. I believe there are two ways in which we can assert our claim in Antarctica. One is by occupation of the bases in the Australian Antarctic Territory and the other is by doing significant science work and I assure the honourable member that we will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The deterioration of business confidence as a result of Fraser Government policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, a look at the 'Finance and Business' page of one of Australia's major daily newspapers this morning tells the story. Let me quote some of the headlines. Here is one: 'Fraser's gloomy picture indicates depreciation will go unchecked'. That headline refers to the value of the Australian dollar and it leads to another headline, relating to the relationship between the Australian dollar and the United States dollar, which reads: 'returns to the level of 1976'. Here is another headline: 'Interest crashes through 20 pc-new highs feared'. Why the fuss about Neville Wran's 18 per cent when we see in the Sydney Morning Herald 'Finance and Business' page headlines such as 'Interest crashes through 20 pc-new highs feared'? Another headline reads: 'The patient: take as prescribed'. The story reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government is facing a balance of current account deficit of about $8,500m this financial year according to its major economic departments.
Again, on the same page of the same newspaper this morning there is this headline: 'Unemployment to rise-bank' with the story underneath stating:
The National Bank has painted a bleak picture for unemployment in 1982 in its latest monthly summary.

Referring to a greater incidence of industrial disputation and an acceleration in wages growth-to an enormous extent both are the result of Government policies , or a lack of them-the article goes on to state:
Together these developments suggest that the year ahead will be a difficult one .

Mr Speaker, I have not yet referred to the headline covering the relative collapse in the share market. But what I have read, I repeat, from one page of one of today's newspapers, is sufficient to show that my language in this discussion of a matter of public importance in this House is temperate. Is it any wonder that there is a deterioration, indeed a grave deterioration, in business confidence? This fickle thing called confidence is enormously important . It governs to a great extent the level of investment in jobs. To be responsible for a reduction in confidence, as this Government is so responsible, is a serious matter of public importance. It involves the livelihood of thousands of people and their standard of living; indeed, the standard of living of thousands in addition to those who are unemployed because of insufficient investment.

Business confidence is inextricably linked with consumer sentiment. Out today is the Roy Morgan Research Centre's index of consumer sentiment for the month of January 1982, prepared in association with the University of Melbourne's Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research. I am told that that document shows that consumer sentiment fell by between five and six points from November last year to January this year. I understand that the result is by far the lowest January result ever measured-nearly 17 points below the average index result for January since the survey commenced. January is a month which is known for its comparative optimism. In previous surveys that the Roy Morgan Research Centre and others have done around the community they have found that optimism is great in January.

A firm interpretation of this document is that consumers are comparatively at their most depressed level for the over nine years since this survey got under way. Why is this so? Honourable members need not take my word for it. The objective assessment of the surveyors, Roy Morgan and the Institute of Applied Economics, is that the unseasonable gloom is understandable in the light of increasing and new taxes, together, of course, with a cancellation of promised tax cuts, which is just another of the messages of yesterday's 'great' statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Of course, it is also due to a quickening of the rate of inflation and is no doubt the result of record levels of interest rates, particularly for home purchases, and of the devastatingly high rate of unemployment. All of these grave factors are the result of inept Fraser Government policies.

I will give in greater detail some of the indicators of our level of business activity, that is, the low level of which I am complaining. According to the index of business sentiment of the Australian stock exchange's all ordinaries index, at 31 December 1980 the level was 713.5. At 31 December 1981, after six years of this Fraser Government which was to lead us back to economic recovery, it was down to 595.5, a fall of 16.5 per cent. Yesterday, 9 March, the figure was down to 463.6, a further fall of 22.1 per cent over the nine and a half weeks of 1982 and, of course, a fall of 35 per cent since the beginning of 1981. What does this mean? It means that investors have wiped off more than one-third of the valuation of the Australian corporate sector-and more than a half of this collapse has occurred in the past two months. That is just one indication. If we look at the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd index of factory production, the situation, in one word, is languishing. According to its figures , in December 1981 the production index was 113 and in June 1981 it was 112. That represents virtually no growth for the first half of 1981-82.

It is the same story with retail sales. As at January 1982, in seasonally adjusted terms they had grown only 0.2 per cent from the December 1981 figure. That represents an annual rate of growth of 2 1/2 per cent compared with inflation of 11.3 per cent. What is the conclusion we can draw from that indicator? Of course, it is that retail sales, as is the case with production and as we heard in the story from the Australian stock exchange all ordinaries index, are now stagnant. The story could be told in this Parliament; I have the details to do so but unfortunately too little time in which to give them.

There has been an 8.8 per cent fall in building approvals in the private sector . Production statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics tell the same story as did those of the ANZ Bank series. I wish to quote from a recent information booklet from the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia which has hit the desks of all honourable members.
To give but one example, the following statement appears:
. . . there is an appalling lack of real effort being made to ensure that the inequities suffered by small business . . . are removed.
Similarly, the Metal Trades Industry Association, in its pre-Budget submission, stated:

It is clear that the relatively high value of the Australian dollar remains a major factor in Australia's poor trading performance, the year ended June 1981 being the first annual trade deficit Australia has experienced since 1968.

The Association is putting the blame where it is due, of course-with the managers of this economy, one of whom, the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Sir Phillip Lynch), is presently at the table ready to answer for the Government in this debate. I believe that he will not be able to provide a credible answer to the facts that I have related.

The honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child), who is to follow me from this side , will be illustrating the deterioration that has occurred in business confidence by drawing attention to the plight of small business, by citing bankruptcy statistics, and by saying something about the problems of the housing and motor vehicle manufacturing industries, with which she is familiar. Therefore, if I do not mention them further it is because their case is in competent hands.

All of the sad facts that I have given fly in the face of the rhetoric with which we have been pounded by the present Prime Minister at elections in 1975, 1977 and 1980. I propose to quote only one or two of the promises that were made then. I have many examples before me. In relation to taxes, this sort of promise was made in 1975:
We will no longer be able to rely on the secret tax increase of inflation.
In 1977 the Prime Minister said:
This Government has brought the largest and fairest tax reforms ever made.
In 1980 he said:
We have fulfilled our commitments to reform the tax scales.
We heard a similar story in relation to small business. In 1975 the Prime Minister said:
Small businesses and private companies in particular are in a desperate state. We will change the tax rules which operate against them.
In 1977 he said:
Australian people will not accept a return to high taxes.
In 1980 he said:
The tax laws will be altered to make it easier for small business to build up their reserves.

That is mere rhetoric. These things have not happened. The promises have not been fulfilled, and after six years of this Government we are in a worse mess than we were in when it took over. I have cited just some of the misleading promises that were made. Let us examine again the performance which has led to this deterioration in business and consumer confidence.

Inflation is back into double figures and is running ahead of the average for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. One major cause and effect of this inflation is, of course, spiralling rates of interest. Rates will continue to rise unless we in Australia change our approach to economic management. With higher inflation and interest rates, there is inevitably a fall in demand and a rise in the level of unemployment. The rate of job creation in Australia has now fallen well below the rate of growth of work force numbers. The labour market has deteriorated over the last 12 months, and that trend is continuing.

It gives me no pleasure whatsoever to be so gloomy, but when we fail to face facts squarely and recognise that the Fraser Government's policies have been a woeful failure, we merely postpone the day for changing those policies. It is only when we face the facts squarely that they will be changed.

Yesterday's Prime Ministerial so-called speech to the nation was an example of how vulnerable we are to deception. The theme of the speech was: 'These are tough times internationally, but you can trust us. We are not to blame. We are responsible economic managers. More blood, sweat and tears will get us through. Batten down the hatches. Stay with our hard-line monetarist policies and we shall pull through these times together.'

To use a colloquialism, that is just balderdash. It is a deception. We must not be vulnerable to that sort of talk, particularly from a prime minister in a parliament. Yes, we know that the international climate is not healthy. No one denies that, least of all those on this side, but it is all the more reason why we should not pursue the stagnation-creating policies of the past six years. We do not want any more of the stop-go recipes for disaster of the monetarist marketeers-the sorts of policies that we have had in recent years. We want no more threats that inflationary wage demands will be met by squeezing credit and thus generating even higher interest rates. It is just not a viable economic policy. As soon as the economy gets going, what happens? This Government puts another clamp on it. I am not talking about an industrial relations policy; it is the Fraser Government's instinctively confrontationist formula for industrial war instead of achieving peace.

We need instead a prices and incomes policy. Only Labor can negotiate this. We need what can follow from such an anti-inflationary strategy-a more expansionary budgetary policy creating greater demand leading to more production and to more jobs-and an easing of the monetary restraints in place at this time. I refer to the credit squeeze to which I drew attention in Question Time today. We would not let these restraints go altogether but would ease them so that interest rates would come back down through the roof. They have gone right through the roof as a result of the disastrous policies of Labor's political opponents.

Speeches such as the one we had to endure yesterday from the Prime Minister are the last things this country wants. We can see the international realities; we do not have to be told again about them. We want policies which will promote investment, production and employment-policies which will restore higher living standards to this country. In short, we desperately need a change of government. While we have this present collective leadership-I do not blame just the Prime Minister; the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) is equally culpable and to blame for the ideology which is permeating this Government and the wrong policies which follow from that ideology-the same wrong ideology will prevail. Instead of new hope it will mean more pessimism, more deterioration of confidence. I can illustrate that deterioration of confidence by reading from Australian Business magazine, which suggests that liquidators are saying that other Associated Securities Limited types of crashes will occur in the near future. That grave expectation follows the present Government's monetarist policies.

I have indicated that the Labor Party, when it gets the chance following 1982, after six years of disappointment, will pursue different economic policies for this country. I have given some indication of the way we will go with our more expansionary policies built on a prices and incomes policy. We intend to proceed in that way. That is in marked contrast to the failed policies of the Fraser Government which have lead to the sad deterioration in confidence and performance of recent months and years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It ill becomes the Opposition to raise this matter of public importance today because the Australian Labor Party, as would be well known throughout the community, is anti-business in its philosophy and anti-business in the development of those policies which directly reflect that philosophy. Let us be under no misapprehension as to what the real issues are. The Australian Labor Party is committed to socialism and not to free enterprise; the philosophy which sees the 'profit' motive, the very heart of business incentive, as a dirty word. The Australian Labor Party has as its objective the extension of public ownership, not the development of enterprise based on individual initiative and individual incentive.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party is committed to additional government spending, support for excessive wage increases, a bourgeoning bureaucracy, increases in the Public Service and a reduction in the size of the working week. These are the policies which would so detrimentally impact upon the business community that they would significantly erode the strength of the private sector and prospects for industry and commerce in this country, as was so lamentably manifest in the difficult Labor years of 1972 to 1975. But the Labor Party would go further. It would withdraw significant business incentives-I refer to the investment allowance-which are an essential part of that economic and industrial policy which encourages industry to invest, to grow and to be self-reliant and strong.

So much for the Australian Labor Party and the matter of public importance which has been raised in this House. If any further exemplification is required of the truth which I have identified today, then certainly it must be clear in the policies of the Australian Labor Party Opposition in Victoria. Let me say that those policies are anathema to what this State requires and would not enable Victoria to take advantage of the many opportunities of the 1980s and beyond. The Victorian Labor Opposition, following the same policies which the Federal Opposition pursues directly in this House, would destroy the investment prospects of the most significant manufacturing State in the Commonwealth.

The true index of business confidence is the rate of business investment taking place both from domestic and international sources in the Australian economy. This index demonstrates beyond doubt that business has complete confidence in the Fraser Government policies and puts paid to the veracity of the assertions made by the Opposition today. Investment in Australia has shown remarkable growth in the last few years after plummeting in the post-1973 period. Last financial year real business invesment rose 21 per cent to almost 12 per cent of gross domestic product after being around 10 per cent of gross domestic product or less for several years. Investment expectations, on all major surveys, point to further real growth in 1981-82. It has been estimated that real business investment will grow by 15 per cent in 1981-82. The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics' survey of business expectations indicates that investment will grow by at least this amount. In current dollar terms, manufacturing investment is expected to increase by 26 per cent in 1981-82 following the growth of 46 per cent during the course of the past year. For the mining sector preliminary ABS data shows that investment in 1981-82 is expected to be 65 per cent up on the result of 1980-81.

I remind the House that if there is any real index of confidence by the Australian business and commercial community it is the confidence of manufacturers, large and small, and of businessmen and women prepared to back their business judgments with significant dollar investments of the type that are taking place at present. In the September quarter 1981 the real value of manufacturers' sales rose by 0.6 per cent to be 2.9 per cent above the September quarter 1980. The ABS statistics indicate that output in manufacturing rose over 1981, with good gains recorded in the three months to January 1982. But if we seek, as surely we must in this debate, to place Australia in the international perspective one can, of course, state that among the economies of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries Australia has stood out over the past two years in terms of growth and stability. It is this record of growth and stability, engendered by the Government's economic and industrial policies, that has made Australia an attractive investment prospect for overseas investors . The Foreign Investment Review Board recently reported a 10 per cent increase in proposals put before it in 1980-81 compared with the previous financial year. Private investment capital inflows in 1981 totalled $6,406m, a very substantial increase over the 1979-80 level of $1.840m.

Confidence is also reflected in the number of business formations now taking place. For example, actual new business registrations in Victoria in 1980-81 were 31,000, an average of around 125 per working day. This is a 6 per cent increase on 1979-80, when 29,000 new businesses were registered compared with 688 business bankruptcies. Furthermore, almost 19,100 new companies were incorporated in Victoria in 1980-81, 30 per cent more than four years ago. Similarly, there were 19,000 new business registrations in Queensland in 1980-81 , which is again an increase of 6 per cent on the previous year. This is, of course, a reflection of Australia's strong economy, a further indication of our fiscal and monetary policies and of Australian business confidence in them. There is no doubt that more Australians are finding it worth while to go into business for themselves and that more are making a success of it.

These clear signs of confidence demonstrate the success of this Government's economic record, despite the current international economic uncertainty to which I referred in this House yesterday. Since the Fraser Administration came to office in 1975 our consistent objective has been to correct the gross economic distortions of the Labor Government and to re-establish a stable economic environment. The record shows that we have been successful in restoring economic growth in this country. Real gross domestic product rose 3 per cent in 1980-81 and is expected to grow by 3.5 per cent in the current year. Inflation rates have been generally below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average in recent years. Private consumption rose by 3 per cent last financial year and we expect a similar rise in the current year.

This record is most encouraging but it could not have been achieved without the Government's consistent and disciplined approach to the economic management of Australia. It could not have been achieved if we had not pursued with vigour and determination policies aimed at bearing down directly on inflationary pressures- policies which have involved restraint on government expenditure and on the money supply; policies directed towards the resistance of pressures for excessive wage and salary increases and shorter working hours at this time.

Budgetary programs have concentrated on reducing the growth in government expenditures, which in real terms increased by 21 per cent in 1974-75 and which as a share of GDP reached a peak of over 30 per cent following the Budget brought down by the then Treasurer Hayden. Over the past five years Budget expenditures have risen by only 1 1/4 per cent a year in real terms and as a share of GDP are now less than 28 per cent. These policies entailed the elimination of deficit spending. As a share of GDP the Commonwealth deficit has been reduced from 5 per cent to a very small proportion this year. As a result we have been able to staunch the inflationary creation of money which results from spendthrift government policies. Lower inflation and the knowledge that there is a government firmly committed to combat inflation are the greatest incentive that firms can have in committing the very significant sums necessary to bring about Australia's growth.

The restoration of an optimistic environment for investment has been one of our prime objectives. Australia continues to attract very strong interest from investors around the world. Australia's continued growth rests squarely on the fact that since 1975 this Government has provided Australia with stability and economic policies based upon a belief in the free enterprise system. We stand for growth and the opportunities and security which non-inflationary growth provides in this country. I believe the way of life that we enjoy in Australia to be the best in the world. It is interesting for me simply to refer in passing to a statement made recently by Emeritus Professor A. H. Pollard writing in the February Australian Economic Trends newsletter. Professor Pollard said:
Australian families are taking home higher incomes, paying proportionately less tax, and enjoying better health and more overseas travel, . . .

Our policies have helped Australians to build a better life for themselves. This is what our philosophy is all about. The living standards and vibrancy of the life which we take for granted today are the great legacy of the Liberal Party of Australia, a sure guarantee that this philosophy can keep Australia moving in the period ahead. If one had any doubt as to the credentials of what the Opposition is putting forward in this House today, let me say that it is not this Government's policies that concern Australian businessmen and women, but their bitter experience of Labor policy. In government the Labor Party took a series of steps which crippled and demoralised Australian industry. It withdrew the investment allowance and allowed inflationary wage increases to take place. Australian manufacturers lost the capacity to compete internationally. Now those policies are more radical than ever before. They propose a comprehensive range of new taxes and disincentives to industry and investment-unprecedented income tax rates, a wealth tax, a resources rental tax, withdrawal of the investment allowance and specific regulatory action to impede productivity growth. These policies would encourage unions and further price workers directly out of jobs because of support by the Australian Labor Party for excessive wage and salary increases at present.

Of particular and immediate concern is the fact that these Labor policies are currently being put forward to the people of Victoria. The policies that Labor has announced would destroy business confidence utterly and would bankrupt that State. They would plunder the State's financial reserves and drive investment away because of the very significant influence of the socialist left throughout Victoria. The Labor Party does not have a business blueprint to lead this country effectively into the 1980s and nor do the policies which it pursues and supports have the confidence of the business community. This Government is committed to a vigorous free enterprise economy with incentive for achievement. This commitment and the policies put forward by the Fraser Government have the confidence of the Australian business and commercial community. The Government rejects the matter of public importance which is before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) has misled the Parliament today about Labor's industry policies in the Federal sphere. He asserts wrongly that Labor is against profits. He misleads. Labor recognises that capital must have a reasonable return if there is to be new investment in jobs. It is part of our policy. Why does the Minister mislead the House? Is it because he cannot win an argument on the facts as they stand? He has strung together a lot of figures but nothing else. That is about all we have ever had from his side of the House. As the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) pointed out yesterday in his state of the nation address to the House, the international economic climate is bad. We would all agree that the world economy is worsening and will, in fact, continue to do so. We in Australia have not yet felt the full impact of the economic difficulties which are being experienced overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: Why then, if the worst is still to come, are we in Australia in such a deplorable state? Interest rates are rising, inflation is rising, unemployment is rising, money is getting tighter and more and more businesses are going bankrupt. Regardless of overseas trends business confidence in Australia is at an all time low. The Prime Minister cannot, with a few words in this House, sheet all the blame elsewhere. He, his Government and his Government's ill- judged economic policies are the greatest threat to our domestic economic welfare. It is obvious, and we on this side of the House have repeated the fact over and over again, that the hard line monetarist policies that this Government has followed have been disastrous. The policies are not working. The Prime Minister has in turn blamed Labor's three years in office for all of our ills. He has blamed the trade union movement and now, finally, he says that the health of the Australian economy will depend entirely on the health of the international economic climate. That horse will not run. The Prime Minister, through his confrontationist attitude to the unions, has exacerbated industrial problems. If we are threatened with a wage explosion, the blame lies with this Government, through its failure to support wage indexation, its failure to control inflation and to protect interest rates and through its failure to inspire confidence in business houses throughout Australia. The blame lies with the Government also in its failure to restructure the taxation system and give some relief to the pay-as- you-earn taxpayer, who is faced this year with a massive 22 per cent increase in tax.

Typical of the Government's failure to inspire the business world with the confidence necessary in these difficult times is its handling of the plan for the car industry, an industry in Australia that is an enormous employer in areas in which employment is scarce. The Government has made a complete mess of this industry, but to compound the errors with a plan that goes up to 1990 is extraordinary. The plan announced in December 1981, after months of unease among car manufacturers and component manufacturers alike, will make it more difficult for the Australian car industry to remain in existence. The plan does not come to grips with the biggest single manufacturing problem in Australia, or with the needs of a manufacturing industry in current or future Australian conditions. It will not increase employment in the industry. It will create uncertainty-the first enemy of confidence.

As usual, when this Government has to operate in a difficult economic climate- albeit one of its own making-it lacks the courage and ability to plan realistically for the future. Having no confidence in itself, it fails to inspire confidence in others. Even its own back benchers reacted angrily to the car plan, and the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) was reported in the Age on 22 December as having said that it was 'a ludicrously complicated plan which would cost jobs and would not benefit consumers'.

The complete lack of confidence that this Government inspires can be pinpointed accurately by the state of the building industry. This has long been accepted as the economic indicator in Australia, and at present it is sick. Fewer and fewer private and public buildings are being started, and confidence in any improvement in this area is at an all-time low. As each month's figures come through, they are worse than the previous ones. We need desperately to rejuvenate the building industry.

Nowhere is the lack of confidence and the disastrous economic climate having more effect than on small business. Estimates by both government and private researchers show that there are between 350,000 and 400,000 small businesses in Australia. Leaving government employment aside, it is estimated that small enterprises account for between 50 per cent and 60 per cent of total employment in the private sector. One could rightly assume that small businesses must flourish and look to the future with confidence if we are to have a healthy Australian economy. Their success is intrinsically linked with our prosperity and employment. Unfortunately, anything that this Government has done to assist our thousands of small businessmen is of a token nature. This Government responds to lobbying from big business and from multinationals, but its record with the very heart of our nation is deplorable.

Relatively little specific data about the small business sector and its many component elements is collected, even though resources provided by the Federal Government enable facts and figures to be gathered, assessed and reported. Most other advanced countries, such as West Germany, Japan, Sweden and Canada, have sophisticated specialised small business programs and policies. Considering the size and economic importance of the small business sector, governments ought to be prepared to commit resources comparable with those dedicated traditionally to the rural and manufacturing sectors. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter that I recently received from the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia.

The letter read as follows-
COUNCIL OF SMALL BUSINESS ORGANISATIONS OF AUSTRALIA
Chairman
D. M. Gibbons
8 March 1982 Dear Member,
I invite you to study and think carefully about the contents of the enclosed booklet.
It discusses the most Government neglected but possibly the most economically important sector of the Australian economy SMALL BUSINESS.
Until a few years ago Governments were totally disinterested in our economic ' Cinderella'-she was quite subservient to the big ugly sisters in industry, commerce, mining and rural/farm production.
