The results of the lack of confidence evidenced among the manufacturing and business sector of the nation are clearly illustrated by the fact that bankruptcies during the early 1970s averaged about 2,000; in 1979-80 they had increased to 4,979; and in 1980-81 they had increased to 5,154. That is about a 250 per cent increase in the number of businesses that have failed in this deplorable economic climate. The bankruptcies are highest in Victoria, which has easily won the unenviable title of 'Bankruptcy Capital of Australia'. The introduction of legislation for a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on many more items has almost been the last straw for many of our beleaguered small businesses. Even the Treasurer admitted in this House that it would put increased strain on their limited resources. That is part of the reason why the Australian Labor Party, both in this House and in the other place, is determined that that sales tax legislation must be defeated. It is the last straw to businesses that are staggering under the burdens they have already.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has the extraordinary record of presiding over the worst economic recession since the 1930s, with a promise only of more of the same to follow and a reiteration that the Budget strategy is working. If that strategy was to bring the country to its knees, then yes, it is working. If it was to destroy the confidence of the business sector, yes, it is working there also. What this country is really looking for at the moment is a government that is prepared to have enough confidence in itself, in its industry and in its people to admit that the Budget strategy is wrong and that the last six years have been six of the worst years the country has faced. While this Government has another 18 months or so of governing it should have the courage to admit that it is wrong. Before it capsizes our economy it should turn back and take a different direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradfield Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance brought on by the Australian Labor Party is closely allied to many of the arguments put forward yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his speech on Australia's economy. That speech clearly identified the fact that in a difficult international situation Australia is in an outstanding position compared with other countries. That position is due to the policies of this Government and it could not have developed if there had been a lack of business confidence in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is in a position today that is envied by many of those countries that were considered to be the economic leaders, such as the United Kingdom and the United States of America. Deep down they would have loved to have adopted some of the economic policies that this Government adopted some five or six years ago when it came to office. There are many indicators that clearly show that this country is progressing and does have the confidence of the business community. This is a free enterprise government. It is a government that relies very heavily on the business community and on the confidence of that community. When we look at some of the statistics we find that since this Government came to power the number of people employed has increased by 500,000-half a million people. In 1975 those employed in Australia stood at 5.9 million. Today that figure is 6.4 million. Without business confidence that progress cannot happen. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) mentioned in his speech the words of Professor Pollard, who said that Australians have never had it so good. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 February 1982 Professsor Pollard is quoted as saying:
. . . in the six years to 1981, average household income had risen in real terms by 5.4 per cent, while the purchasing power of average weekly earnings had risen by 6.3 per cent.

The Professsor also said that statistics revealed that the number of registered motor vehicles per 1000 people had increased by 18.6 per cent, from 419 to nearly 500. I mention that particularly because both members of the Opposition who spoke in the debate mentioned the motor vehicle industry as an indicator that shows a lack of business confidence in Australia today. Yet if we were to look at the current sales of new motor vehicles we would find that they are stable and showing confidence. If honourable members want to move on to some other statistics to back up our claims they should look at the latest bulletin issued by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd dated February 1982. It starts off by saying:
Between 280 and 300 petroleum exploration wells are expected to be drilled in Australia in 1982. This is double the 1981 exploration programme . . .

If there was not business confidence in Australia would such predictions be made , predictions that entail such massive investment? I do not think so. The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) also quoted from the ANZ Bank's latest publication dated 23 February 1982. Yet the opening remarks of that publication, addressing retail sales, also state:
. . . retail sales-. . . in 1980-81 rose strongly, being nearly 5.0 per cent higher than in 1979-80. This was the first significant recovery since the 1974- 75 recession.
The 1974-75 recession was at a time when the Australian Labor Party was in government in this country. The article goes on to state:
The accompanying chart shows real retail sales growth recovering in 1980-81 . . .

Once again, if there is a lack of business confidence is it possible for retail sales to grow? The answer, of course, is no. Yet Labor members stand here and, throughout all their speeches, talk about the gloom and doom of the economy of this country. They are doing this country a great disservice in endeavouring through their talk in this place to influence people to think that somehow or other some great economic disaster is happening here.

This Government has been forced to take many unpopular decisions. It is unfortunate that the correct economic decisions are not always popular. We have had policies to restrain government spending, to restrict the money supply, to bring down the rate of inflation and to achieve a balanced Budget. We have not adopted these policies because somehow or other in a temporary way they hurt people. It would be lovely if we could govern the country and do everything that is popular, but that is not the way to do things. We have adopted these policies over the years to put Australia, as we have done, in a most favourable economic condition. If honourable members look at the record, as the Minister for Industry and Commerce has pointed out, they will see that over the last six years of this Government Australia has become more competitive internationally. Businesses have increased their profitability. The greatest factor of all is that other countries have shown their confidence in Australia by their willingness continually to subscribe overseas capital in this country. Australia today offers sound opportunities. Certainly changes will be necessary for our industry and our business people because the world is changing, the demands of people are changing. Of course we must always keep this in mind to make sure that our businesses can prosper along the right lines.

The Opposition continually uses as an indicator the number of bankruptcies in a country. It is completely incorrect to use bankruptcies as such an indicator. There will always be bankruptcies in business. Bankruptcies are a cleansing implement in the business world; they do not allow an inefficient business to continue in operation. Without bankruptcies we would only be thrusting upon the community economic businesses which would be supplying products at a stupid price to Australian consumers. Bankruptcies will always be necessary.

At the moment there is a tremendous drain of funds into resource development in this country. The level of investment is set out in the statistics which I have cited. I know that the drain of funds into the capital intensive industries has caused temporary problems in this country but Australia will benefit from this resource development. This investment in resource capital intensive industries will reap a great reward for all Australians in the future. I know that Australia is affected by overseas happenings. As the Prime Minister said yesterday, we cannot ignore what happens overseas but through the sound economic policies of this Government, often unpopular policies, Australia is in a sound position to go ahead and benefit from them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Minister:
Sales Tax Legislation
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers particularly education publications and books of a religious nature, is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, a clear infringement of our democratic freedom, and that no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Cass and Mr O'Keefe.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That librarians and library users throughout the nation call for the exemption of books, periodicals and newspapers from the imposition of sales taxes.

That tax exempt status of libraries and schools will not protect them from general cost increases which sales tax and its collection will cause. Indeed, exemption claims on millions of items per year will themselves add to the cost burden of both libraries and suppliers.

This tax is socially injurious and unworkable, and a burden on education, science and culture. Your petitioners therefore pray: that your honourable House will exempt books, periodicals including newspapers from the proposed sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Connolly and Mr Duffy.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5% on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman,Mr Street and Mr Viner.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned, wish to protest against the Federal Government's proposed 2 1/2% sales tax on books, newspapers and magazines. This proposed tax is a tax on knowledge and an impediment to the free flow of information.
We respectfully request that these items be exempted from the sales tax provisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Connolly and Mr Howard.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, and that no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Herbert respectfully showeth that by imposing a sales tax on newspapers, magazines and books the Government intends to not only tax essential educational materials, thus adding to the ever increasing cost of educating Australia's greatest natural resource-our children, but also the organs of free speech, which ensure the survival of our democracy, as well as affecting the livelihood of Australian authors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Government will not enact legislation to introduce sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned residents of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The proposed sales tax of 2.5% on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the Budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with educational books, clothing, footwear, newspapers, buildings and food wrappings, as these sales taxes impose a further burden on home builders, families and children; inhibit the free flow of information through books and newspapers; and reduce employment opportunities.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should: Exempt these items from the proposed sales tax legislation, as requested by the Senate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross,Mr Dean and Mr Katter.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of sales tax on items concerned with home building, clothing, footwear, books and newspapers, wrapping for food.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to exempt these items from the proposed sales tax as requested by the Senate to avoid such taxes on necessities of life becoming a further burden on home builders, families and children or inhibiting the free flow of information through books and newspapers or reducing employment opportunities for people in the industries concerned and beyond.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howard,Dr Jenkins and Mr Peacock.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth;
(a) That the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Coleman,Mrs Kelly and Mr Spender.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That Federal funding of children's services, which has been reduced by almost 50% in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least 1975-76 levels in real terms, so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia.
That Budget allocations for children's services be spent in full for the purposes designated.
That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of users and should be dropped forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howard,Mr MacKellar,Mr Sinclair and Mr Spender.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lionel Bowen,Mr Coleman and Mr MacKenzie.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

1. The proposed two and one half per cent sales tax to be levied on clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings manchester, building materials, books, magazines, newspapers, packaging and wrapping materials, hand tools, etc., would be regressive and inflationary.
2. The burden being carried by pensioners and other people on low incomes is becoming insufferable and is sapping the morale and assaulting the dignity of a large and proud section of our Nation.
3. We therefore request that the proposed legislation be not enacted, and further, that existing sales taxes on all household goods be removed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howard,Dr Jenkins and Mrs Kelly.

PETITION.TITLE: Youth Accommodation Services Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned about the possible closure of the Westernport Youth Refuge because of inadequate funds made available under the Youth Accommodation Services Program (A joint Department of Community Welfare Services and Department of Social Security Program).

Over a 12-month period more than 500 young people have been assisted by the refuge. If it is forced to close then many homeless young people in the Westernport Region will be left without any assistance at all.
Your petitioners in duty bound humbly pray that additional funds be provided under the youth Accommodation Services Program.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy,Sir Phillip Lynch and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That Family Radio Ltd represents the largest single interest group in the community-i.e., christians-who do not have a voice in public broadcasting commensurate with their representation:
That prime time access to existing broadcasts by christian groups is virtually non-existent, and access at other times is fast disappearing:
That, by comparison with other capitals, Brisbane is entitled to at least one more category 'S' FM broadcasting licence:
That there appears to be no prospect of the release of further category 'S' FM licences in the near future for Brisbane:
That satisfactory fulfilment of the aims of family radio and its expansion can only be achieved by broadcasting in its own right under licence:

That Family Radio has a responsibility to the large support groups which have contributed substantially to its developemnt, to achieve the aims in broadcasting and community work for which it was established:

That there is an urgent need for the kind of service and support that Family Radio can provide to other community groups through the particular type of intergrated programming proposed by the company under a full-time licence.
And that pruned Government resources are obviously insufficient to advance the development of public broadcasting as originally intended.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will support Family Radio's application for a broadcasting licence and will enable more category 'S' FM licences to be made available in Brisbane.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Jull.

PETITION.TITLE: Registration Fee for Periodicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, respectfully ask that the Australian Government request Australia Post to review the recently introduced annual registration fee for periodicals.

With many periodicals produced for distribution to members in small numbers only, this new impost, together with the recent increases in postage rates, considerably adds to the administrative costs of small clubs and organisers, whose activities are non profit, and are directly involved in community activities.
Accordingly, we earnestly request this review, with a view to smaller clubs and organisations, at least, being exempted from the requirements of annual registration.
We thank you in anticipation of your support.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife and Mrs Kelly.

PETITION.TITLE: Perth Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that total annual aircraft movements into and out of Perth Airport are expected to more than double over the next fourteen years.
Your petitioners note that this will produce a dramatic increase in noise pollution in the surrounding suburbs, particularly those directly beneath flight paths.
Your petitioners further note that unlike Great Britain, Australia has no legislation to allow payments of compensation for injurious affection.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That the Minister for Transport implement a curfew banning traffic movements at Perth Airport between 11.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m.
(2) That legislation be introduced to allow payment for injurious affection, including compensation for cost of insulation of private and public buildings.
(3) That the planned parallel runway be constructed immediately so as to direct air traffic over the non residential area at Newburn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament as assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who respectfully show their anger and condemnation at the unrealistic low priority given to children's vacation programmes and other children's services which has resulted in the withdrawal of funds from programmes which provide an essential community service.
We protest at the disastrous effects this will have on parents and children.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government provide public funding for all children's services including vacation programmes to ensure quality services are available for all children and parents who require it.
Further that funds be immediately released to prevent closure of Vacation programmes for the 1981/82 financial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the basic rate of pensions and rent allowance is not sufficient to meet present day needs.
In light of the 20 per cent increase in M.Ps. salaries pensioners are being unfairly treated.
Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. Basic rate of pension be increased to 30 per cent of the average weekly earnings.
2. Rent allowance be increased from present $5.00 weekly to $20.00 weekly.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 26th January, 1788, is the date of first white settlement in Australia , and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia,
and this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Rumanian Government is committing genocide against the three million strong native born Hungarian population in Rumania, as defined in Articles II, and III, of the United Nations Convention on the Crime of Genocide, which facts are well documented in the reports of the Amnesty International, the Minority Rights Group, the International League of Jurists, etc.

That the Article IV of the Convention states that: 'Persons committing genocide or any other acts enumerated in Article III shall be punished, whether they are constitutionally responsible rulers, public officials or private individuals'.

That the Article VIII of the Convention states: 'Any contracting party may call upon the competent organs of the United Nations to take such actions under the Charter of the United Nations as they consider appropriate for the prevention and suppression of acts of genocide or any of the other acts enumerated in Article III'.

As Australia is a Contracting Party to the Convention on Crime of Genocide, and that the Joint Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defence has already established precedents by having investigated Human Rights violations in other countries.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

1. That the Joint Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defence to take up an investigation into the alleged genocide activities of the Rumanian Government against its three million native born Hungarians in Rumania; and

2. That if such investigations should establish that Rumania has been engaged in acts of genocide against its Hungarian minorities to call upon the competent organs of the United Nations to take such action under the Charter of the United Nations as they consider appropriate for the prevention and suppression of acts of genocide or any other acts enumerated in the United Nations Convention on Crime of Genocide.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Purchase of Land near Melbourne Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we request the Commonwealth purchase the land known as Lot 40, Melrose Drive, which is bounded by Melbourne Airport, for the purpose of increasing the buffer zone and providing public open space, thus enhancing the beauty of Melbourne Airport and protecting the adjacent residential area from being intruded upon by industrial development.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will give earnest consideration to this most vital matter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Tobacco
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That any increase in excise duty on cigarettes would be a further burden on smokers, would adversely affect employment in the tobacco manufacturing industry and aggravate the already high levels of inflation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will reject any proposal for an increase in tobacco excise.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the NHS and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by toxic shock syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

1. Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under the Therapeutic Agents (not under 'Cosmetics' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

2. After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

3. Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's sales tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its sales tax legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The Government proposes to impose a sales tax of 17 1/2% on manufactured pet foods which were previously exempt.
2. That this new tax will impose an unreasonable burden on pet owners, many of whom are pensioners and citizens in receipt of a small income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its sales tax legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Non-interest Bearing Accounts
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The proposals announced by the Minister Senator F. Chaney to amend the Social Services Act limiting the sum of money to be retained in a current/cheque account to $2,000 for a single pensioner and $3,000 for a married couple are unacceptable in that:

Both single and married pensioners are, at regular intervals, faced with meeting recurrent expenses in connection with home maintenance, insurance, motor vehicle repairs and so on, for which no financial provision or assistance is given;
that such recurrent expenditure, when coupled with unexpected or unplanned expenses arising from family crises, health or funeral costs, may quickly exceed the proposed new limits; and
no other repository, except a current/cheque account, is able to provide funds as conveniently, or at short notice to pensioners.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to consult with the Australian Pensioners League and other pensioner groups in order to arrive at just and equitable legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of the Commonwealth submits:

That the mining of uranium in Australia, the proposed development of a uranium enrichment industry in Australia, together with the possibilities of resumed atomic weapons testing in the Pacific and dumping of radioactive waste in this region, constitute a serious threat to the health and well-being of all Australian and Pacific people for many generations to come.
Your petitioners request that your Honourable House will:
1. Stop the mining and export of Australian uranium, except for medical and research purposes.
2. Actively oppose the development of uranium enrichment and nuclear power plants, the testing of nuclear weapons, and the disposal of radioactive waste in the Australian and Pacific region.
3. Significantly increase research into alternative energy sources.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ethnic Broadcasting
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the report on migrant services recommended that the extension of ethnic radio should be phased over the next three years to cover all capital cities and provincial centres with large numbers of migrants.
That the Federal Government has continually ignored this recommendation.

That the 1981-82 allocation for two Special Broadcasting Service run stations in Sydney and Melbourne is $4 million, while the then operating 13 public broadcasting stations servicing the rest of Australia were allocated only $450, 000.
That the total budget allocation for public ethnic broadcasting stations for 1981-82 is $400,000, and represents a cut in funding of 25% in real terms.
That this amount falls short by $120,613,000 of the assessed minimum required to maintain the current level of public ethnic broadcasting.
And that a distinct bias has emerged in the Federal Government's attitude to ethnic broadcasting, discriminating against ethnic communities outside Sydney and Melbourne.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government more equitably distribute funding to ethnic broadcasting, and that such funding be provided by legislative enactment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
''We wish to voice our objection to the latest rises in telephone charges of Telecom Australia, deeming such charges to be unnecessary and outrageous.''

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government will: ''Cause Telecom Australia to make telephone services available to every Australian home by bringing their installation and rental charges in line with North America and abolishing fees for local calls.''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) the imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) those students and potential students from social groups currently under- represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. Post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
2. The visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
3. The Minister of Education immediately clarify the Government's attitude to the re-introduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Curfew at Eagle Farm Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That noise levels created by aircraft using Eagle Farm Airport already constitute an annoyance and inconvenience to those residents living near the airport and along flight paths.
That relaxation of the Eagle Farm Airport curfew to allow any aircraft including TAA's airbus to fly into and out of Eagle Farm Airport between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. would:
(a) Substantially increase the inconvenience and annoyance caused by aircraft noise because the operation of aircraft at this time would seriously disturb people's sleep;

(b) contradict and negate a commendable undertaking made by the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, the Honourable Ralph Hunt, in reply to a question on notice in the Parliament, that the curfew will remain on the runways at the existing site at Eagle Farm Airport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will not approve the application of TAA-or any other airline-to relax or withdraw the curfew at Eagle Farm Airport.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government and Telecom management have presided over the deliberate scaling down of Australia's telegram services, to the disadvantage of those poorer people in the community who cannot afford telex or telephone facilities and rely on the telegram service in time of emergency;

That the Government and telecom management have undermined the telegram service by increasing the unit cost of telegrams by over 130% in four years with the result that the use of telegrams as a form of communication has fallen by approximately 60% in that time.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government and telecom management retain the telegram service at a standard and cost that will not disadvantage the ordinary citizen.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Non-interest Bearing Accounts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That any proposal by the Government to threaten pensioners' entitlements to fringe benefits by establishing a ceiling on the allowable amount of savings in non-interest bearing accounts is completely unfair and does not take account of the natural need of all pensioners to maintain some savings for occasional expenses such as house maintenance.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with any such proposal, and should instead direct its attention to those pensioners who enjoy extremely high levels of extra income yet manage to remain within pension eligibility guidelines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that :

Whereas the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Neil Brown announced on the 24 September 1981 that a Community consultation would be held before the future of the Community Youth Support Scheme would be decided;
And whereas they appointed a Task Force to carry out the consultation, whose membership was confined to public servants and did not include community representatives;
And whereas only a few weeks have been allowed for the consultation;

And whereas the terms of reference within which the Task Force is conducting its consultation are extremely narrow making it impossible for a future Community Youth Support Scheme to provide general community support to young unemployed people;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
(1) Extend the time allowed for the consultation until at least May 1982.
(2) Change the composition of the Task Force to include representatives of CYSS Management Committees, Project Officers and participants.
(3) Widen the terms of reference to enable a consultation about a general community support program for unemployed youth throughout Australia.
(4) Allocate funds to CYSS programs and other appropriate organisations to facilitate the consultation.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aids for Disabled
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the PADP (Program of Aids for Disabled People) Scheme, while in theory an excellent initiative, is not at present funded to an adequate level to provide all the aids listed. This will result in a substantial shortfall which will restrict the ability of the States to fully implement the scheme.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will increase the funding for the PADP Scheme to enable its total implementation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Adelaide Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Reprsentatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) the present Adelaide airport is not a suitable locality for an international airport,
(2) residents in the vicinity of the airport suffer considerable inconvenience and discomfort from aircraft noise,
(3) the provision of international services at the existing airport, as announced by the Government, will further exacerbate the noise problem and safety hazard at Adelaide airport.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Government take immediate action to purchase a suitable site for an international airport outside the metropolitan area, and that planning for the new airport begin as a matter of urgency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia will place in jeopardy to existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading the number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the amount of permissable extra private income before the age and invalid pension is reduced was last increased in September 1972, and that a relaxation of the means test is long overdue.
And your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Government will increase the means test for pensioners to the same relative level as applied in 1972, taking into account increases in the cost of living in excess of 100 per cent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxes and Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We, the people who have signed this petition ask all parties, Labor, Liberal, Democrats and others, to stop the latest increase in taxes and the forever increases in taxes which hit all people of the country of Australia in all goods and consumer goods and we call for a referendum on taxes and interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action through tax relief and other measures to avert any further effects of increases in interests on home mortgage loans which cause detrimental financial, social and psychological pressures on families, and in many cases, positive hardship.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

(b) impair the day labour system and undermine the capacity of Departments of Main Roads to train staff and test road construction concepts;
(c) have a disruptive effect on the employment opportunities available in small communities;
(d) reduce the flexibility of the Department of Main Roads to handle emergencies caused by flood or fires; and
(e) ultimately increase the cost of road construction at taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government withdraw this disruptive proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decision of the Federal Government to discontinue the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) will further reduce the prospects of young Australians for employment, and place additional undue hardship on the unemployed.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australian Parliament assembled:

The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of undersigned Christian citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant variety rights in other countries has had adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise the maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties so crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic material from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the etablishment of plant variety rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop ''normalised'' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide ''noninstitutionalised'' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from or cope with attendant care.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to repeal the budget amendments to sales tax legislation and to withdraw its sales tax amendment bills which add sales tax to presently exempt goods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hunt, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HUNT

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable members will be aware that clauses precluding spouses of persons involved in industrial action from receiving unemployment and special benefit were deleted by the Government from the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 during its passage through the Parliament. Those clauses were subsequently introduced into the Parliament, in the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981, which the Senate failed to pass last November after it had been passed by this House. This Bill reintroduces that Bill. Before October 1979, the Social Services Act precluded payment of unemployment benefit to a person who was a direct participant in a strike. However, it enabled unemployment benefit to be paid at the married rate to the spouse of a person ineligible for unemployment benefit on those grounds. The Act was subsequently amended to provide that unemployment benefit payable to the spouse of a person engaged in industrial action was to be at the single rate. A further amendment precluded payment of special benefit to a person who, because of industrial action, was not qualified to receive unemployment benefit.

This Bill proposed that, for so long as a person's spouse is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit because of involvement in industrial action, unwillingness to undertake suitable work, or failure to take reasonable steps to obtain such work, that person will also be ineligible for unemployment benefit. Additionally, a person will be ineligible for unemployment benefit for so long as payment of that benefit to the person's spouse is postponed because of that person's misconduct as a worker, because he has become voluntarily unemployed or because he has failed to accept an offer of suitable employment. Consistent with this approach, special benefit will also be withheld from persons not eligible for unemployment benefit in these circumstances. The Government has decided, however, that if a person is precluded from receiving unemployment benefit and special benefit, in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support, that person's spouse may be eligible for special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children. This will ensure that cases of actual hardship can be assisted, in contrast with the present position in which the social security system can be called upon in circumstances in which there is no actual need.

We are not here concerned to discuss the merits of strike action as contrasted with other means open to employees in dispute with their employers to resolve these disputes. What we are concerned with is how the cost of strike action is to be borne. The Government holds strongly to the belief that these provisions should become law. In the case of the provisions relating to industrial action, we do not believe that Australian taxpayers should be asked to subsidise strike action through the social welfare system. The policy underlying this Bill is that a person, when he chooses to take strike action, should act in the recognition that he takes responsibility for the consequences of his action, both for himself and for his family. Strikers make the decision to strike against the rest of the community, and they, not the rest of the community through the welfare system, must bear the financial consequences. Trade unions, whether acting through their officials or by the vote of their members, should equally recognise that a decision to initiate industrial action will have consequences for all members and their families which the community should not be asked to bear through the welfare system.

This is the proper perspective from which to consider the measures proposed in this Bill. The Government is not swayed by emotional and misleading arguments which seek to deflect attention from and misrepresent that fundamental concern. The issue is quite clear, and we do not intend to be drawn into the kind of fruitless debate which seeks to direct attention away from the issue. The Bill is not an anti-strike Bill, but one which aims at restricting the community subsidisation of strikes. The legislation, as it stands at the moment, permits a situation in which trade unions can choose to strike, knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members can be largely insulated from the financial effect of their actions. The benefits sought in many industrial disputes are ones which to the striker are economic, such as increased pay, a shorter working week, or special allowances. Not infrequently, strikes are settled on a basis that effectively compensates those who have gone on strike for pay lost during the duration of the strike.

The point to be emphasised is that to strike is a matter of choice. Generally, it is one taken by the membership of a union to promote its own interests and only its own interests. It is taken against the interests of the employer and, what is directly relevant to this Bill, it is not taken in the interests of the community as a whole. Indeed, the effect of strike action is often in conflict with the interests of the community as a whole or some part of it. Frequently, the community suffers as a result of strike action. This may be reflected simply in inconvenience or in terms of direct economic cost. Furthermore, in a larger sense, it may be said that in the longer term the community always suffers as the cumulative result of the strike action is to decrease the availability of goods and services, and sometimes to do great damage to particular sectors of the economy, or to particular employers. These matters need only to be mentioned to make clear the absurdity of any argument that benefits should be paid to strikers or their families, and should be paid by the community at large. It is the community at large that provides through taxation the funds from which strikers are currently paid the benefits that this Bill proposes to eliminate.

There have been numerous cases in which the wives of strikers, who have appeared to have no genuine intention of joining the work force themselves, have registered for work in places such as mining and construction towns where there is no real possibility of employment for them. This has enabled them, under the existing legislation, to obtain unemployment benefit, and so transfer to the taxpayer some of the real cost of the industrial action taken by their husbands. The burden so thrust upon the community is far from light. For example, honourable members will recall that from 15 July 1981 to 28 September 1981 some 600 people were involved in a strike concerning the use of apprentices during industrial action at the Utah Development Co. mine in central Queensland. Four hundred and seventy-one wives claimed unemployment benefit at a cost of around $ 40,000 per week, making a total cost of some $450,000. The Australian public is attacked from two directions. First, it has to bear the personal disruptions, inconveniences and associated costs that result from the strike. In addition, it is then called upon to meet the cost of providing income support for the families of those involved in the strike.

To act to correct this situation is not to punish or to penalise the families of strikers, but to ensure that people accept the financial consequences of their own actions and do not look to the rest of the community to bear the costs of workers and their families. Similarly, there is no good reason why the community should automatically and immediately be expected to assume, through unemployment or special benefit payments, the normal financial responsibilities of people who are not willing to work, who voluntarily and without good reason give up their job, or who are dismissed through their misconduct. This is happening at present because the spouses of such people can register for employment in their own right and, if they are unable to obtain employment, can claim unemployment benefit both for themselves and for their 'dependent' spouses .

In this situation, however, as with the strike situation to which I have earlier referred, the Bill also provides that, if a person is precluded from receiving unemployment or special benefit, that person's spouse may receive special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children, in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support. The very existence of this provision belies the quite false charge that the Bill will in any way 'punish' or 'penalise' families.

Mr Deputy Speaker, we believe that whether people refuse to work because of industrial action or whether, in some other way, they show themselves unwilling to enter or remain in the work force, there is no reason why the rest of the community should shoulder their financial responsibilities. This Bill prevents them from manipulating the social security system to shift the consequences of their actions. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTRICITY SUPPLY AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hodgman, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Act 1962 to provide for the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority to restrict the use of electricity in the Australian Capital Territory following the declaration of a state of emergency by the Minister.

The Territory currently derives 60 per cent of its bulk supply of electricity from New South Wales, the balance coming from the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. Due to the significant amount of total bulk supply of electricity that is purchased from New South Wales the Authority is particularly vulnerable to emergency situations occurring in New South Wales. Shortages of electric power and energy in New South Wales have resulted in emergency situations and requests to the Authority to reduce load.

In the past the Authority has sought to achieve this reduction by means of public appeal to its customers for voluntary restraint, coupled with reduction of the supply voltage. These methods have not, however, resulted in a reduction as significant as that achieved in New South Wales by means of legislation enabling the supply to be restricted. In order for the Authority to respond effectively to emergency situations and to provide an equitable distribution of the available supply, it is absolutely essential that the Authority have power to impose restrictions.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is indeed unfortunate in the extreme that this action is necessary. New South Wales has supplied a large part of the electricity requirements of the Territory since 1929. With the exception of the early post- war years and a short period in 1973, the Government has been able to rely with confidence on a continuation of adequate supply. This, unfortunately and regrettably, is no longer the case. Since June last year, the supply of electricity from New South Wales has been uncertain. We cannot be confident that the situation will improve.

The power supply problems in June 1981 were due to a combination of factors, the principal one being the shutdown caused by plant difficulties in two large generating units combined with major industrial problems. This is, in fact, what the Electricity Commission of New South Wales has itself admitted in so many words. The failure of two more large units at Liddell power station in November 1981, exacerbated again by industrial problems, caused the imposition of restrictions yet again.

Some relief was expected with the commissioning of the first generator at the Eraring power station but this too has been delayed for months-again due to further industrial disputes. The Government believes that the chain of events is such that it must be fully prepared to deal with future emergencies-for the welfare of the national capital and its residents.

The Bill makes provision for the Minister to declare, by notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, that an electricity supply emergency will exist during a period, not exceeding 28 days, specified in the notice. The Minister may make such a declaration where he is satisfied that the supply of electricity available in the Territory is, or is likely to be, so inadequate for the needs of the Territory as to require restriction of use. The declaration may be revoked by the Minister by notice in the Gazette if the need for restrictions cease.

During a period of emergency the Authority may, by order in writing, restrict the use of electricity in the Territory. Details of the emergency orders to be made will be published in the Gazette and in a newspaper circulating in the Territory. Details may also be published by radio or television broadcast if the Authority considers it appropriate to do so. The orders will come into force on the date of gazettal or such later date as is specified in the Gazette. The orders will be subject to disallowance. They will be laid before both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days of their making and either House may then disallow them within a further period of 15 sitting days.

Honourable members will recall that on 26 May 1981 my colleague the Attorney- General (Senator Durack), avowed the Government's commitment to the principle that delegated legislation and the like should be subject to review by parliament. In accordance with this principle, provisions for the disallowance of instruments of a legislative character should, unless there are good reasons for variation, incorporate the substance of certain traditionally accepted safeguards, such as requirements that they be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days of their making and that a motion for disallowance must be dealt with within 15 sitting days.

While, in accordance with this principle, emergency orders will be subject to disallowance, the very nature of emergency orders and the time constraints which an emergency imposes, necessitate, on this occasion, the incorporation of a further procedure in the Bill to make parliamentary review more effective. Accordingly, in making the emergency orders, the Authority will comply with guidelines made by instrument in writing by the Minister, which have themselves been subject to disallowance by the Parliament. The guidelines will be laid before both Houses of Parliament and either House of Parliament may, within five sitting days after a copy of the guidelines has been laid before it, pass a resolution disallowing them. If neither House disallows the guidelines, they will come into force at the expiration of the five sitting days. The Authority cannot make an emergency order unless the guidelines are in force.

The period for disallowance has been limited to five sitting days because it is considered essential that the Authority be in a position to impose restrictions this winter. This might not be possible if the disallowance period were the usual 15 sitting days. In addition, it may be necessary for the Minister to amend the guidelines quickly if they prove inadequate to deal with the emergency at hand.
Persons, including bodies corporate, who without reasonable excuse contravene or fail to comply with an emergency order shall be guilty of an offence.

During an emergency a justice of the peace may, where he or she is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that a contravention of, or a failure to comply with, an emergency order has occurred, grant a search warrant effective for a specified period, to an officer or employee of the Authority, authorising that officer or employee to enter and search the land or premises for the purpose of ascertaining whether such a contravention or failure has occurred. The Bill will bind the Crown. I commend the Bill to the House.
