PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill concerns two international financial institutions-the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation. They are two of a number of international financial institutions that have played a steadily growing role in the world economy since the end of the Second World War. They began with an international conference in 1944 at Bretton Woods in the United States where it was agreed to create a World Bank and an International Monetary Fund. The Bank was intended primarily as a source of long term loans for the reconstruction of war devastated countries and subsequently for assistance in economic development in what are now called the developing countries. On the other hand, the International Monetary Fund was designed for the stabilisation of international payment arrangements, providing short term credits for that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The World Bank is a group of three institutions-the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Development Association and the International Finance Corporation. The annual report of the World Bank notes :
. . . the common objective of these institutions is to help raise standards of living in developing countries by channeling financial resources from developed countries to the developing world.

The World Bank is owned by the governments of 135 countries which subscribe its capital. The Bank finances its lending operations primarily from its own borrowings in world capital markets. The Bank loans generally have a grace period of five years and are repayable over 20 years or less. They are directed towards developing countries at more advanced stages of economic and social growth.

The International Development Association was established in 1960 primarily to provide assistance to the poorer developing countries on terms that would bear less heavily on their balance of payments and bank loans; that is, its lending is on concessional terms. The International Finance Corporation was established in 1956 to assist less developed countries by promoting growth in the private sector of their economies and helping to mobilise domestic and foreign capital for that purpose. The International Monetary Fund is a type of relatively weak international central bank. Its main functions are to help maintain order in the international money market and to provide short term loans to member countries to tide over temporary balance of payments deficits. Each member of the Fund is assigned a quota expressed in special drawing rights.

Special drawing rights are a form of international money created by the International Monetary Fund and distributed to each member in proportion to its quota. New allocations of special drawing rights are made from time to time when the membership of the Fund decides a new issue is required. This quota is determined partly by economic criteria such as the size of the country's gross domestic product and international trade, and partly as an outcome of political negotiations. The size of a country's quota largely determines its voting strength in the Fund, as well as its allocations of special drawing rights and the amounts of credit it can obtain from the International Monetary Fund's facilities.

There are now 140 members of the IMF including most non-communist countries as well as some from the Eastern bloc. The Western industrial countries command a large majority of the votes in the International Monetary Fund's decision-making bodies. Over 60 per cent of total votes are controlled by Western industrial countries. The oil exporting, less developed countries have 10 per cent of the vote and other less developed countries have just under 30 per cent. The principal distinction between the two main international financal institutions is that the World Bank makes long term loans to member governments for the purpose of economic development and the International Monetary Fund provides short term balance of payments support to its members.

The purpose of this Bill is to increase Australia's shareholding in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and in the International Finance Corporation. In 1980 the Bank's Board of Governors adopted a resolution which increased the authorised capital stock of the Bank by approximately $US40, 000m. The resolution provided for the portion of the shares to be subscribed by each country and for payment arrangements. Insofar as they affect Australia, these arrangements are embodied in the Bill and involve a payment by the Australian Government to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development of $US54.62m to be paid over four years. Similarly, the International Finance Corporation approved a resolution in September 1977 authorising an increase in its capital. This resolution was supported by Australia and the Bill under debate authorises the purchase and payment of $ US10m for the addition of shares to which Australia is entitled. The Opposition supports the Bill.

The effective functioning of these international financial institutions is vital for the efficient and equitable functioning of the international economic sysytem. It is to that matter that I now wish to turn. The prospects in all areas of world trade, whether in commodities or manufactures, in energy or in the activities of multinational corporations, are greatly influenced by the functioning of the world monetary system. Predictable rates of exchange encourage investment as well as trade; erratic and fluctuating rates discourage both. Stable rates increase the confidence of asset holders, whether surplus oil producers or other potential investors. Likewise, an adequate flow of international liquidity smooths out cyclical fluctuations, makes protection of domestic markets less necessary and enables commodity producers to ride out deteriorating terms of trade. Yet throughout the 1970s the international financial system was in disarray. There have been massive balance of payments imbalances, exchange rates have fluctuated wildly, there has been explosive growth in the debt of developing countries and the international financial institutions, particularly the International Monetary Fund, have been seen to be relatively ineffective and subject to growing criticism.
An international conference of organisations concerned with the North-South debate, regarding the international monetary system, was held at Arusha in Tanzania in mid 1980 and concluded:

The post-1945 monetary system has broken down. The ensuing inflationary and speculative disorders inflict serious damage on the majority of peoples and countries. It is imperative to conceive and negotiate new monetary structures and procedures.

The defects of the International Monetary Fund were clear throughout the 1970s. Those of the World Bank are becoming clearer, particularly through the manipulations of the United States under President Reagan. I will discuss the two institutions in turn. I refer first to the International Monetary Fund. The Fund is controlled by a Board of Governors which normally meets once a year, the members of which are normally Ministers of Finance or Treasurers. Under the Board of Governors is an Executive Board responsible for everyday business, which is composed of full time representatives meeting weekly in Washington. Six members of the Executive Board are permanent representatives of the countries holding the largest numbers of shares-namely, the United States, the United Kingdom, West Germany, France, Japan and Saudi Arabia. The other 15 members are elected by groups of countries.

The United States holds about 22 per cent of the votes and since major decisions require 75 per cent to 85 per cent of the votes, the United States has a virtual veto. Western industrialised countries together hold 61 per cent of the votes, the oil exporting countries 10 per cent and other less developed countries 29 per cent. This voting pattern has been little changed since its adoption in 1945 and is therefore outdated. It is clear that with this pattern of control the interests of the North, the developed countries, are likely to predominate over those of the South, or the less developed countries. Thus President Nyerere of Tanzania has accused the International Monetary Fund of exploiting Tanzania's economic difficulties in order to interfere with the management of its economy, of being a device by which 'powerful economic forces in some rich countries increase their power over the poor nations of the world' and of trying to impose on them an anti-socialist ideology of economic and social development.

The IMF failed to make much contribution to easing the oil crisis which began in 1974 even though one of its principal tasks is to provide financial assistance to members suffering from balance of payments disequilibria. For example, while the aggregate current account deficit of non-oil, less developed countries from 1974 to 1979 amounted to $233 billion, net IMF credit financed less than $10 billion of this. Commercial bank recycling loans were far larger, even with interest rates of up to 20 per cent per annum-far above the charges of the IMF. Even in the crisis years of 1974-75-I am referring to the international crisis years-there was no increase in the number of standby agreements with the less developed country members and the real value of these credits was well below that of the 1970 to 1973 level. In 1978-79 there was actually a net return flow from less developed countries to the IMF. The consequence of this was that many of the less developed countries could manage their balance of payments only by cutting the volume of imports and their development aspirations.

Although there have been absolute increases, aggregate quotas in the Fund have fallen dramatically as a percentage of the total volume of international trade, from 14 per cent in 1950 to 4 per cent in 1978. It is therefore not surprising that governments complain that the Fund seeks to influence policies to an extent which is out of proportion to the limited assistance it can offer. Many less developed countries would have made fuller use of the Fund's facilities had they not feared the short term conditions which the Fund would have imposed on them.

Many legitimate criticisms are made of the IMF's approach, even after discounting for the criticisms which are naturally applied to any central bank attempting to maintain financial discipline. For instance, President Nyerere said that he naturally expected that the IMF would lay down certain conditions for using any of its facilities, conditions which he expected to be not ideological and relating rather to the honesty and efficiency with which the money was used. He even accepted that Tanzania could justly be asked how it was planning to deal with its problems in the medium or longer term. However, he continued:

Tanzania is not prepared to devalue its currency just because this is a traditional free market solution to everything and regardless of the merits of our position. It is not prepared to surrender its right to restrict imports by measures designed to ensure that we import quinine rather than cosmetics, or buses rather than cars for the elite. . . . Cuts may have to be made in our national expenditure, but we will decide whether they fall on public services or private expenditure. Nor are we prepared to deal with inflation and shortages by relying only on monetary policy regardless of its relative effect on the poorest and the less poor. . . . When an international institution refuses us access to the international credit at its disposal except on condition that we surrender to it our policy of self determination, then we make no application for that credit.

Such comment gives a clear indication of the concern that Third World countries have as to the conditions for assistance laid down by the IMF. It is clear that the predominantly Western or Western-trained staff of the IMF hold values which are in conflict with those of many of the developing countries with which they deal. It is clear also that there is a similarity in the Fund's approach to each of the countries with which it deals which gives inadequate attention to the individual conditions of those countries. The package of policies required of countries seeking a high level of credit often includes ceilings on credit to the public sector, the liberalisation of trade and payments, a currency devaluation and cuts in real wages.

Another of the fund's inadequacies from the start has been its preoccupation with balance of payments of deficit countries and the lack of sanctions against surplus countries. For example, so long as members of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries earn large surpluses and add to their reserves and the industrialised countries continue to shift much of the burden of this to non -oil less developed countries, these countries must continue to show deficits. Their deficits are simply the accounting counterparts of OPEC's surpluses. Whilst adjustment appears feasible for an individual country, the same is not possible for less developed countries considered as a group so long as the rest of the world remains in surplus. The international monetary system thus induced the South into deflationary policies in pursuit of an adjustment which, considered collectively, is impossible to achieve.

To summarise, the International Monetary Fund is seemingly insensitive to the aspirations and political imperatives of its less developed country members. The limited ability of private international banking flows to meet the needs of less developed countries at a time of massive global imbalances adds further urgency to pleas for reform of the Fund. Greater flexibility in the conditions the Fund imposes is required, especially to reduce the deflationary bias of an international financial system that exerts no comparable leverage on persistently surplus countries. The power structure within the IMF should be changed and conditions for its lending relaxed. If the Fraser Government is as concerned about Third World countries as its Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) makes out, it should be actively supporting such measures.

At the same time as the IMF has sometimes exerted too much power over individual countries' economic policies, it has also too little power over international currency markets. The IMF is dwarfed by the vast totals of largely uncontrolled money in national currencies which make up the sum of world liquidity. The world monetary system of the 1970s is, in a real sense, out of control and a global catastrophe could be brought about by the maverick whim of market opinion or the malice of a substantial group of holders of reserve currencies. The Brandt Commission noted that the first requirement for international monetary reform was that full account must be taken of the great expansion of private international money and capital markets, such as the Euro- currency and the Euro-bond markets and the Asian and Middle Eastern currency markets. The Brandt Commission recommended reforms including improvements in the exchange rate regime, the reserve system, the balance of payments adjustment process and the overall management of the system to permit fuller and more equiable participation of the whole international community.

The first specific recommendation by the Brandt Commission is for the issuing of an improved special drawing right on a much larger scale. New special drawing rights should be issued in a way which favours the developing countries which presently bear high adjustment burdens. This is consistent with the amended articles of the IMF which were accepted in Jamaica in 1976 and which enjoin each member to collaborate with the IMF and its other members in 'making the special drawing right the principal reserve asset in the international monetary system'. In view of this article, which Australia supported, the opposition of the United States of America and Australia at the annual IMF meeting last September to the proposal from less developed countries for a modest issue of special drawing rights is incomprehensible. At present SDRs are about 2.5 per cent of global reserves. A modest new issue of such special drawing rights would have contributed significantly to easing payments problems of less developed countries without being inflationary. Australia's opposition to this issue of special drawing rights was completely inconsistent with the Prime Minister's rhetoric at the time, for it came at the same time as he was attempting to portray himself as a sympathetic advocate of the South in preparation for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne last October. So much for the genuineness of this Government's concern for the South.

The World Bank has some of the same deficiencies as the International Monetary Fund. Its structure of management and control is the same as that of the IMF, giving it a strong western bias. The values generally shared by its staff are those of Western economics departments of the post war period. Like private banking loans, its credit creates debt repayment problems for borrowers and strictly commercial criteria are applied to its loans. Yet since the election of the Reagan administration it has been the subject of an astonishing assault by the United States Government attempting to impose even more conservative policies. The United States Treasury, headed by Donald Regan, as distinct from Ronald Reagan, has stopped just short of accusing the Bank of encouraging socialism. The Administration failed to budget for the United States contribution to the sixth replenishment in International Development Association funds which was expected for the three-year period 1981-1983. With the retirement of the previous President of the World Bank, Robert McNamara, President Reagan appointed Tom Clausen, previously President of the Bank of America, which is one of the banks most heavily involved in loans to the Third World. Such an appointment is indicative of President Reagan's concern to ensure that the World Bank operations were even more in accord with United States interests than had previously been the case. Thus the Washington Post towards the end of last year reported:

Influential Reagan advisers charge that although the United States has the biggest single money stake in the World Bank, management is not sufficiently influenced by the United States and that Bank is not an efficient agency for carrying out US strategic policy abroad.

From that report it would appear that the objective of the World Bank should be to pursue United States strategic policies but that is certainly not its formal charter. Furthermore, the Under-Secretary of the United States Treasury has publicly expressed the view that the Bank should serve United States interests and that instead of encouraging 'socialism through the government-to-government mode of operations' it should 'lend to the private enterprise system'. It is clear that the Reagan Administration plans to use United States aid even more intensely as a foreign policy weapon. Thus an increasing proportion of aid from a total decreasing level of aid is to be channelled through the Unites States Agency for International Development. Bilateralism rather than multilateralism is the dominant theme.

The Reagan Administration is cutting away even those limited gains for justice and equity which were made during the previous decade. For example, global negotiations about the principal issues involved in prospects for a new international economic order were expected to start under United Nations auspices at the beginning of 1981. Some delay was accepted as inevitable when a new United States President was elected. However, it was not until the Ottawa economic summit held in July last year that President Reagan gave any indication of willingness to participate in the global negotiations. Despite this agreement at Ottawa the United States continued to delay commencement of global negotiations at the United Nations, which was the forum through which they were to be conducted.

At the meeting of the heads of government in Cancun, Mexico, in October last year, which was held to discuss the Brandt report, the United States again agreed to participate in global negotiations but in the most general terms. The most optimistic observers wrote about the 'spirit of Cancun', indicating that the process towards negotiations had taken a leap forward. However, when the United Nations resolution to convene a conference for global negotiations was reactivated after Cancun, the Americans submitted a draft response which merely noted the original resolution and sought to convene a preliminary United Nations conference for global negotiations. In the United Nations semantics 'noting' amounts to giving a proposal the diplomatic cold shoulder. Calling for a preliminary conference rather than for the negotiations proper sets the clock back pre-Cancun and pre-Ottawa. So one year of waiting and high level negotiation has achieved absolutely nothing.

President Reagan has developed a remarkable ability for convincing other participants at international meetings that maintaining the status quo is a major concession. For example, the preliminary meeting to the Cancun conference was hailed as a great success simply because President Reagan had agreed to come , despite the fact that the meeting had reached no agreement about an agenda or even about the issuing of a communique at the end of the Cancun conference.

Three months after the Cancun meeting the joint chairmen, President Portillo of Mexico and Prime Minister Trudeau of Canada, wrote to all participating heads of government emphasising the importance of translating the 'spirit of Cancun' into action. They said:
Three months after Cancun your co-Chairmen are not convinced that this translation is taking place to the extent we had all hoped at Cancun.

United States intransigence is moving the North-South dialogue backwards at an increasingly rapid rate. The tragedy is that despite some sympathetic posturing about the North-South dialogue the Fraser Government has acted very little differently. Despite speaking in more sympathetic terms, the Fraser Government's actions have been little different from those of the Reagan Administration. The support by Australia for the position of the United States in opposing a new issue of special drawing rights has already been mentioned.

There have been no public comments by the Fraser Government to the United States protesting against the distortions and neglect of World Bank and International Monetary Fund policies. The Fraser Government has made no constructive proposals for reform of the international financial system. The share take-up which is authorised in this Bill is no more than Australia's absolute minimal duty. Until Australia takes a leading role in initiating proposals for change to create a more just and equitable international order we will be failing lamentably to take the implications of our location as a Northern industrialised country which is situated in the south sufficiently seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has explained, the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill provides for Australia to take up increases in its capital subscriptions to two international financial institutions-the International Bank of Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation. In the course of my remarks I will rebut some of the suggestions that the honourable member made in the latter part of his speech in reference to this Government, but I am pleased to see that he, on behalf of the Opposition, does support this measure. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is an institution of very long standing. It goes right back to 1947, the beginning of the post-war era of development aid to the poor, the underdeveloped countries of the world. Its primary business is the provision of loans on semi-commercial terms to developing member countries. Up to the end of June 1981 about $US68.2 billion had been provided for projects in all major sectors of economic development. There can be no doubt that this institution is an important and efficient institution for the provision of development assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill, which gives effect to Australia's additional contributions, will, I am sure, command the support of all members of this House. It is an important component of our general multilateral aid effort, which in turn is part of our total overseas program of assistance to developing countries. Incidentally, this assistance is provided mainly by way of a grant, which is in contrast with many other countries. This overseas aid in total amounts this financial year to in excess of $650m, an increase of the order of $100.6m over the previous year. This is an indication of the increasing priority that the Government has given to this area.

As I have said, I am confident that all members of this House will support the measure. I hope also that it will command the support of all Australians. Sometimes we come up against the view that we-Australia, the Government-should not be involved in this area; that we have a duty to our own first and that we should not get involved in such a diverting of resources to overseas countries when there is so much yet needed to be done in this country in respect of the poor in education, health, development and so on. The answer is that it is very much in all our interests to be involved in this process of aid to the developing and poor countries of the world.

In the ultimate the case for doing so can be summed up in the words of former United States of America President Carter. He said: 'You cannot have a peaceful world one-third rich and two-thirds hungry'. In a word, it is the very peace of the world which is, in the not-so-long term, at stake in this area. For the circumstances of underdevelopment-the poverty of the South vis a vis the rich North-and exacerbated in many cases by great power intervention, are a potential source of conflict with the possibility of escalating to world conflict, as assuredly as are the arms race and tension between the East and West. The 'East' refers to the Soviet Union, its allies and proxies such as Cuba and Vietnam, and the West to the United States of America, Western Europe, Australia and so on. There is as great a potential threat to peace in this North-South context as there is in the other. The concern for world peace is overriding and universal. There is also a compelling case, on humanitarian grounds, for the provision of this aid-the obligation of those to whom much is given to help those with much less. Beyond that there is the mutual interest of both donor countries-advanced countries such as Australia-and the donees, the underdeveloped countries in other ways. In particular, there is an interdependence in economic matters. There is a great and increasing mutual dependence as between the developed and the developing countries. It is a matter of straight long term economic self- interest that we be involved in this area.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was saying that the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill authorises an important component of our overall overseas aid effort to developing countries, that is countries of the so-called South-in Africa, the Middle East, Southern Asia, Central and South America-which are poor in comparison with the industrialised developed countries most of which are in the north, of Western Europe, the United States of America, Canada and Japan. Australia is an exception, being a rich country in the south. It is customary to refer to this context as the North-South context. The fact is that living standards generally are very high in developed countries. We think in terms of an income per head of upwards of $8,000 per annum whereas in developing countries income per head may be as low as about $250 per annum. Alternatively one can look at this in terms of parameters such as infant mortality rates. In developed countries, the infant mortality rate is of the order of 15 to 20 deaths per thousand births, whereas in Africa it is about 150 to 200 deaths per thousand. In Latin America it is up to 170 deaths per thousand. In these countries 800 million of the world's population live in the hunger and desolation of absolute poverty. The total population in these countries amounts to approximately two-thirds of the world's population.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said that this measure should commend itself to the support of all Australians, on humanitarian grounds, on the grounds that the circumstances of underdevelopment are as great a threat to world peace as are the arms race and tension between the Eastern bloc and the Western bloc, and on the grounds of plain long-term economic self-interest-recognising the economic interdependence of the developing and developed world, the South and the North as I have just referred to them, the great and increasing mutual dependence of one on the other . There are various ways of expressing that point.

The dependence of the poor countries, the developing countries on the advanced countries for markets, not only for commodities but also for their new manufactures, for development aid and assistance-as provided for in the Bill now before the House-plus private lending from the advanced countries, is well known and obvious. What needs stressing is that the markets of developing countries are absorbing an ever larger share of advanced countries' exports to the point where the demand of developing countries, or Third World countries, is seen by many as the new growth frontier of the 1980s. Over the past five years or so there has been a massive trade deficit on the part of the non-oil developing countries. This was referred to by the honourable member for Gellibrand who led for the Opposition. There can be no doubt that this order of international deficit-financed spending, so to speak, has been quite crucial to the underpinning of world demand and thus to holding up world economic activity to the extent that it has held up over recent years. Unemployment, already very high in many industrialised, advanced countries as was pointed out yesterday, higher than in Australia-of the order of 8.5 per cent in France and the United States and 11.5 per cent in the United Kingdom-would otherwise have been higher still. So I say again, when we talk about aid to developing countries-I concede they are a diverse group of countries but I am taking them together for this purpose-there is a very compelling case on humanitarian grounds, but the case rests also on straight, long-term economic and political self-interest, the interest of all of us in a more stable, workable and peaceful world system.

I have spent a good deal of time in recent years, particularly as a member of the Inter-Parliamentary Union-during the Thirty-first Parliament I had the privilege of being leader of the Australian Parliament's delegation to that body -talking with Third World people, members of parliament and others, and working to devise positions on international economic issues. One becomes profoundly impressed with their point of view when one is engaged in this way. One becomes impressed also with the immensity, the massive proportions, of the problem. Far be it from me to disparage in any way the activities of voluntary organisations such as the Freedom from Hunger Campaign and others. They are of the utmost importance in getting people involved in these great issues in a personal way and in helping to achieve the necessary political will for action by governments . But the magnitude of what is required is such that only governments and large scale commercial activity can come up with the resources on the necessary scale. Hence the importance of this Bill before the House.

I referred to the Inter-Parliamentary Union. Two resolutions were adopted at the sixty-seventh and sixty-eighth conferences respectively held in Berlin in 1980 and Havana in 1981 and I will seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard at the end of my speech. When honourable members have an opportunity to read these resolutions they will, no doubt, detect something of a slant towards the aspirations and policies of the developing countries. But, as I have argued, the problems and the economic and political implications for Australia and the developed world generally are nonetheless real for that. They do convey, I think , something of the gravity of the issues and the concerns of those most affected .

Honourable members will particularly note the great store that is put on getting meaningful, global negotiations under way. The Cancun summit meeting which was held last October-it followed the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Australia-has come and gone and still nothing very much has happened. The honourable member for Gellibrand, when leading for the Opposition, disparaged this Government's activities in this area. In that respect it should be said that Australia has given conditional support to global negotiations and that is in contrast to the United States Administration's unwillingness to involve America in such negotiations. Even more so, I might add, in recent years Australia was out in front in relation to the Common Fund, an institution or a proposal which developing countries have set a great store by. In point of fact, we played a significant role in bringing to the point of conclusion in June 1980 draft articles of agreement in relation to the Common Fund.

We, of course, are a rich developed country. In that sense we belong to the North. But we are also a commodity exporter, and that we have in common with most of the countries of the South. Having something in common in this way with both the advanced countries and the developing countries, this has often meant that in international negotiations Australia has been able to play the role of effective intermediary.

As I have said, these issues in the so-called North-South context mesh closely with the other great context of issues threatening the peace of the world-the East-West context, as it is referred to, namely, the confrontation between the Soviet Union and its allies, on the one hand, and the West, on the other hand. The cost of maintaining the nuclear, the military balance, on which the general peace of the world directly depends, is enormous. In toto-this includes expenditure on the awesome nuclear arsenals of the super-powers-the world spends about $450 billion annually on arms, which works out at about $1 million a minute. It is an enormous dead weight of cost which inevitably acts as a brake on what can be achieved in the North-South context, what can be done to assist the poor, the developing countries, and to lift their living standards. The complexity, the challenge, the utter frustration, in this area is perhaps no more graphically underlined than by the statistic that in 1980, which is the latest year for which figures are available, the non-oil developing countries, which are generally the poorest, received in official development aid some $US33 .5 billion, whereas those same countries spent $US38.4 billion on military spending-a sum greater than what they spent on education, health and welfare put together.

One would like some sort of formula which linked the receipt of aid with effecting a decrease in spending on arms in these countries. Indeed, the Germans , in recent dealings with some Latin American countries, tried just that. But, generally speaking, that is a Utopian approach-a dream world. What must not happen is that this sort of pattern of things should paralyse our resolve to press on with policies to assist the developing world. The only realistic approach is to keep pressing ahead simultaneously on both fronts to which I have referred. That is, we must pursue actively, as this Government does, the objective of arms control and disarmament. We must do what we can-we cannot do much in this first area-to encourage further strategic arms limitation negotiations between the super-powers, we must encourage the negotiation of a comprehensive test ban treaty, and-here we can be effective-the further reinforcement and commitment to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, these things in the nuclear area, and other restraints in the area of conventional weapons. We must do those things as well as give support for effective peace processes, as, for example, in the Sinai as this Government is doing. We must do those things, on the one hand, and at the same time, enter into meaningful negotiations and commit adequate resources for the purpose of assisting the development of the Third World. There is no other course open to us. I commend this important measure to the House.

Having made reference to the Inter-Parliamentary Union, I now seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard as an addendum to my speech the two resolutions which were adopted by the Inter-Parliamentary Union.
Leave granted.
The resolutions read as follows-
THE THIRD UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT DECADE; ITS ECONOMIC, SOCIAL EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC, CULTURAL AND EVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS
(Resolution adopted without a vote*)
The 67th Inter-Parliamentary Conference,
Deploring the unsatisfactory results of the first two United Nations Development Decades,
Concerned at the adverse development of the economic and social situation of the developing countries,
Noting that the world trade system and the international monetary system contribute to worsening the inequalities between developed and developing countries,

Stressing the imperious need for radical structural changes in the world economy and in international economic relations on the basis of the application and strict observance of the principles of equal rights, national independence and sovereignty and mutual advantage,
Recalling:
(a) The previous resolutions of the Inter-Parliamentary Union on the establishment of a new international economic order;
(b) The Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States;
(c) The Declaration and Programme of Action for the Establishment of a New International Economic Order adopted by the UN General Assembly in resolutions 3201 and 3202 (S-VI);
(d) The Lima Declaration and Programme of Action, adopted by the Second General Conference of UNIDO in 1975;
(e) The declaration of the Conference on Primary Health Care (Alma Ata, September 1978);
(f) The decisions adopted by UNCTAD V (Manila, May 1979);
(g) The Declaration of Principles and Programme of Action adopted by the World Conference on Agrarian Reform and Rural Development (Rome, July 1979);
(h) The Programme of Action adopted by the World Conference on Science and Technology for Development (Vienna, August 1979);
(i) The Colombo Declaration on Population and Development adopted by the International Conference of Parliamentarians (Colombo, September 1979);

(j) The resolution on ''Protection of the family and general care of children and youth in connection with the International Year of the Child'' adopted unanimously by the 66th Inter-Parliamentary Conference (Caracas, September 1979) ;
(k) The results of UNIDO III (New Delhi, February 1980);

(l) The recommendations on a global food strategy, adopted by the UN World Food Council at its third, fourth, fifth and sixth ministerial sessions in Manila, Mexico City, Ottawa and Arusha respectively, and endorsed by the UN General Assembly,

Convinced that peace, security and detente are important factors for a continuous economic and social development of all States and that effective measures of disarmament would make it possible for resources now absorbed by military purposes to be used for economic and social development, particularly of the developing countries,
Alarmed by the disorders in the international monetary system and their economic and social consequences, more especially for the developing countries,

Aware of the urgent need to approach effectively the pressing questions of raw materials, energy, trade, development, money and finance within a comprehensive, consistent and simultaneous framework constituted by the series of global negotiations pertinent to the Third Development Decade,
Convinced that in order to secure the success of a community's development programmes, adequate food, health and educational levels must be ensured,
Very concerned at the unsatisfactory progress made in the different international economic negotiations, including the agreements on various commodities and on official development assistance,
Worried by the growing burden of the external debt servicing of the developing countries, particularly the poorest of them,

Convinced that only firm political will on the part of the Governments of the developed and developing countries can promote a new international economic order capable of reducing the gap which separates the developed from the developing countries,

Reaffirming that the economic performance of developed countries and the activities of transnational corporations are still major obstacles preventing any constructive step towards the establishment of the New International Economic Order,

Appealing to all peoples and parliamentarians who aspire to progress, freedom and justice to give fresh impetus to the initiative to abolish the prevailing unjust international economic relations and to establish new international arrangements and institutions corresponding to the New International Economic Order,

Very concerned at the incomplete and unsatisfactory results of the Eleventh Special Session of the UN General Assembly and mainly at its failure to conclude the arrangements to launch the global negotiations on economic co-operation for development as a necessary element to implement the goals and objectives and policy measures of the International Development Strategy for the Third UN Development Decade,
1. Calls upon Parliaments and Governments:

(a) To act with a high sense of responsibility and international solidarity for the present and future of the whole of mankind, displaying political will so that the new UN Development Decade leads to the attainment of the objectives of the New International Economic Order and to the eradication of under-development , and effectively meets the requirements imposed by the more rapid development of the developing countries;

(b) To make efforts, in the context of the new International Development Strategy, to comply with the quantitative and qualitative targets and time- frames included in its goals and objectives and policy measures, including specific commitments on the part of all countries, the developed countries in particular, and to establish the monitoring mechanisms thereof during the next Decade so as to ensure that the pace of development of the countries concerned in the coming years is appreciably faster than in the Second Decade;

(c) To take the necessary measures for the prompt adoption of the procedures and agenda of the round of global negotiations on international co-operation for development, preserving the central role of the UN negotiating conference, while taking into account the functions of Specialized Agencies, so as to contribute decisively to the early implementation of the goals and objectives and policy measures contained in the International Development Strategy;

2. Reaffirms forcefully the need to promote the conclusion of international commodity, raw materials and food resources agreements enabling those concerned to implement their development plans in the best financial conditions, and to increase offered development assistance and diversify it, particularly by improving the terms on which it is granted and ensuring the intensive participation and initiative of developing countries in identifying their priorities according to their national policies and plans;

3. Reaffirms also the commitment of developed countries to devote 0.7 per cent of their gross national product by 1985 as official development assistance to developing countries, and the need to find and implement ways and means of channelling these resources in favour of the implementation of national and regional development plans and programs in developing countries; transfer of resources to developing countries should be free of any political or economic terms and/or conditions; and, in addition, the concessional element should be increased; developed countries should commit themselves in advance to official development assistance transfers to developing countries;

4. Draws the attention of the parties concerned to the need to make sure that co-operative development projects should conform to the laws, regulations and ethical requirements of the developing countries; such co-operative projects should also be flexible and should not be used to impose any particular political or economic system on developing countries;
5. Calls on Parliaments and Governments:

(a) To engage actively in the series of global negotiations on economic co- operation for development for solving, with the participation and in the interests of all States, fundamental questions in the raw materials, energy, trade, development and monetary-financial fields;

(b) To promote the establishment of mechanisms to ensure the better stability of the export earnings of the developing countries, the progressive reduction of protectionist measures, the adoption of positive adjustment policies for restructuring and greater market access for the developing countries;
(c) To support the setting up of new mechanisms which should ensure economically substantiated ratios between the prices of staples: raw materials, energy, farmfood produce, manufactured products;
(d) To undertake careful study of the Iraqi proposal on establishing an International Fund to combat inflation, to be financed by both developed and oil -producing countries;

(e) To promote a new international monetary order of a universal nature, including the adoption of measures for guaranteeing an equitable participation of developing countries in the decision-making process;

(f) To reconsider terms and methods of financial resources flow from United Nations specialised financial institutions to meet the urgent needs of developing countries and to conform with the requirements of the international development strategy;

(g) To adopt measures to reduce or cancel the burden of the external debt of the developing countries, and to eradicate the causes of this debt-particularly those due to present international economic and monetary disorders-so that the economic and social progress of the developing countries is in no case adversely affected by external financial obligations;

(h) To undertake specific action in the field of technical co-operation for the training of all levels of management and skilled personnel in the developing countries in technology transfers, guaranteeing technology assimilation by the developing countries and promoting the birth of their own technology, without such transfers being subject to political and economic conditions;
(i) To promote national food and nutrition strategies to combat hunger through an integrated policy and program approach to food production, storage, preservation, distribution and consumption;

(j) To carry out, after thorough studies, realistic national agrarian reform and rural development plans consistent with the specific needs of each of the countries concerned, within the framework of the Declaration of Principles and Programme of Action adopted by the World Conference on Agrarian Reform and Rural Development;

(k) To strengthen economic co-operation among developing countries as a fundamental means to take concrete steps for establishing the New International Economic Order; and in this context, to call upon all developing countries:
(i) To co-ordinate their economic policies at the regional and sectoral levels;

(ii) To establish where necessary new regional economic communities among the developing countries in order to accelerate the implementation of their economic development plans and to ensure the best use of human, natural, financial and technological resources for their individual and collective well-being;

(iii) To intensify the economic activities in the fields, inter alia, of trade, joint planning and joint ventures as a means towards progressive economic performance and increased co-operation among developing countries;

(l) To accelerate the industrialisation of the developing countries, with a view to reaching the figure of a 25 per cent share of world industrial production by the year 2000, as specified in the Lima Declaration of 1975;

(m) To take determined steps for the integration of population programs in all development activities, with the specific aim of increasing knowledge of the interrelationships between population and development;

(n) To take steps to promote the more dynamic participation of women in all development activities within the framework of an employment policy enabling human resources to be enhanced, placing emphasis on adequate education and training programs at all levels;
(o) To adopt an employment policy, particularly for young people, in the context of a strategy enabling full use to be made of human resources;
(p) To adopt adequate national, regional and international conservation programs in order to prevent early exhaustion of some finite resources, as well as rapid depletion of renewable resources;
(q) To give priority to the proposal for a world energy plan which, while guaranteeing the full and permanent sovereignty of each nation, would inter alia :
(i) Rationalise the exploration, production, distribution, consumption and conservation of present energy resources;

(ii) Ensure the systematic exploitation of potential reserves of all types of energy, both traditional and non-conventional, which have not yet been exploited owing to lack of financial or applied research;
(iii) Establish an effective system of action in order to resolve the problems of the less developed oil-importing countries in matters relating to the supply and financing of imports;
(r) To consider thoroughly and subsequently adopt sound environmental policies and standards adapted fully to the interests and priorities of developing countries;

(s) To improve basic health care with emphasis on increased drinking water supply, improved sanitation facilities and the improvement of nutrition and preventive medicine, ensuring primary care capacity for the general population;

(t) To place emphasis on basic education and vocational training and on programs directed towards particular technologies and needed skills, as well as the enhancement of manual work, rather than on traditional formal curricula, in view of the positive links between education on the one hand and increased productivity in both industry and agriculture on the other hand;
(u) To participate actively in the elaboration of a code of conduct for transnational corporations;
(v) To make an active contribution towards the elimination of discrimination and towards establishing equality in the commercial relations of States with different social and economic systems;

(w) To discontinue their economic and financial assistance to all racist entities and r'egimes as defined by the UN resolutions, and to withhold such assistance to r'egimes and countries that do not comply with relevant UN resolutions and international community obligations;
6. Calls upon the Governments of all developed countries and those with sufficient financial capacity:

(a) To increase substantially their financial, material and technical assistance for the development of developing countries, taking into account the proposal that an additional sum of not less than 300 billion dollars at 1977 prices be allocated for that purpose during the Third United Nations Development Decade;

(b) To support the adoption of measures for maintaining interest rates within reasonable limits, facilitating an equitable access of the developing countries to financial markets, to long-term credits and capital markets;
(c) To support and facilitate the efforts of developing countries to achieve their nationally defined development goals and to enhance their managerial capacities;

(d) To ensure broad access by the developing countries, on favourable terms, to modern and advanced technology that is essential to their development, and to eliminate as far as possible discriminatory and unreasonable restrictive practices;

(e) To assist in setting up suitable institutions on a regional or national basis, dealing with the transfer and development of technology in order to enable national capacities to assess, select, adapt and create the appropriate technology best suited to the specific needs of the developing country concerned ;

(f) To devote a proportion of their financial and technical resources to the solution of specific problems relevant to socio-economic development, in accordance with the objectives and priorities set by the developing countries;

7. Calls on the parties concerned to participate actively in defining and implementing the International Development Strategy for the Third United Nations Development Decade, taking into account, inter alia, the need:
(a) To guarantee each country the right, in the exercise of its sovereignty, unrestrictedly to control its national resources and to choose its own way of social and economic development;
(b) To subordinate foreign investments and particularly the activities of transnational corporations in developing countries to the national development plans and priorities of these countries;

(c) To promote rural development and to increase substantially the agricultural and food production of the developing countries and to make the solution of the world food and hunger problem a central objective of the Third United Nations Development Decade;
(d) To promote industrialization with a view to increasing the share of the developing countries in world production;

(e) To make changes in the structure of international economic relations with a view to increasing and diversifying the production of the developing countries and reaching 7% a year as the objective of their economic growth;

(f) To grant their financial and technical assistance to developing countries which are implementing a programme to reform their educational systems and a functional literacy programme for their adult populations;
(g) To define and implement in those countries training programmes suited to their specific conditions and needs;

(h) To elaborate a development policy aimed at the development of productive employment and the constantly increased well-being and quality of life of the whole population on the basis of its full participation in the development process and an equitable distribution of the resulting benefits;
(i) To take into account constantly and more carefully than before the implications of development assistance measures and projects for children and their environment;

(j) To implement in a concrete and effective manner the principles contained in the Declaration of the Conference on Primary Health Care (Alma Ata, September 1978), including the principles of national political commitment and self- reliance in the field of health;
(k) To carry out their development plans and programmes with the utmost efficiency with a view to taking decisive steps to eradicate under-development in favour of their populations;

8. Reiterates the need to take into account the specific needs and problems of the least-developed, land-locked, most seriously affected and island developing countries, with the aim of giving them particular consideration by defining appropriate programmes which could be initiated as soon as possible to enable these countries to benefit from the adjustment of the world economy;

9. Draws the attention of the competent bodies of the United Nations to the desirability of incorporating, in the spirit of the international social justice , the Declaration of Principles and Programme of Action of the World Conference on Agrarian Reform and Rural Development into the Strategy and programmes that will be carried out during the Third Development Decade, with a view to increasing production and productivity and to improving the living conditions of rural populations;

10. Supports the adoption of measures for cutting down military expenditures, part of the funds thus released being used to assist the implementation, within the Third Development Decade, of important projects in industry and agricuture, the extension of the communication network and in other economic branches of the developing countries;

11. Takes note of the fact that the final text of the International Development Strategy prepared by the Special Session of the United Nations General Assembly stresses that the role of Parliaments is essential for the implementation of this Strategy during the Third Development Decade;
12. Calls on the National Groups to take the fullest account of this text in their action directed towards their respective Parliaments and Governments.
THE ENERGY CRISIS IN THE WORLD
(Resolution adopted without a vote*)
The 68th Inter-Parliamentary Conference,

Aware of the advantages for the world community as a whole of establishing international relations, including those in the field of energy, free from any form of domination and exploitation, and the considerable opportunities that would arise for preventing the aggravation of current tensions and crisies,

Convinced that peace and development are intimately and inextricably linked and that both should be furthered simultaneously, to the benefit of all peoples and of the international community as a whole,

Aware that the settlement of the acute problems of the world economy, including energy, and the guarantee of its stability in the interest of the prosperity of all nations call for urgent structural changes in the world economy and in international economic relations, based on the full application and strict observance of the principles of equal rights, national independence and sovereignty and mutual advantage,

Aware that international economic relations are an indivisible whole and that world economic problems, including those in the field of energy, can be resolved successfully only on the basis of the recognition of the common interests of the developed and the developing countries, taking into account the special position of the developing countries,
Aware that the progressive development of the world economy is impossible without an adequate international flow of energy,
Aware of the need to adopt and strengthen international measures for conserving energy that will halt the wasteful practice of consumption that now prevails, especially in the developed countries,
Aware also of the need to develop technologies that will permit the efficient use of existing, new and renewable sources of energy, and bearing in mind the need to safeguard the environment,
Recalling:

(a) The earlier resolutions of the Inter-Parliamentary Union on the establishment of a new international economic order, and particularly the resolution of the 67th Inter-Parliamentary Conference on the Third United Nations Development Decade;
(b) The Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States (resolution 2381 (XXIX) of 12 December 1974);
(c) The Declaration and Programme of Action concerning the establishment of a new international economic order adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in resolutions 3201 and 3202 (S-VI);
(d) The Programme of Action adopted by the United Nations Conference on New and Renewable Sources of Energy held at Nairobi in August 1981;

Emphasizing that it is important to intensify international co-operation for solving the problems of the energy crisis in over to identify and exploit new energy sources, as well as to work out comprehensive national and international programmes to eliminate the unjustified waste of energy resources and to exploit new sources,

Stressing that the international energy problem must be solved in all its aspects, together with the problem of raw materials, trade, development, money and financing, through global negotiations within the framework of the United Nations, in a spirit of co-operation, equity and mutual benefit, and in conformity with resolution 34/138 adopted by the United Nations General Assembly ,

Convinced that a successful outcome of global negotiations on the most significant issues in international economic relations would be an important contribution to the success of the Third United Nations Development Decade, and thus also to the speedier establishment of the new international economic order, while a negative outcome could have adverse consequences for world development, for all forms of international co-operation, as well as for world peace and security,

Convinced that the present situation in the field of energy is related to the state of international economic relations and that the solution is dependent upon the establishment of a new international economic order,

Convinced of the pernicious effects that the world economic crisis has on the weak economies of the developing countries, especially the significant increase in the world price of manufactured goods, food, energy products, capital goods and technology,

Convinced also that interrelated, effective emergency measures should be taken to deal with the current world energy situation so that the developing countries will have access to the energy supplies they need for socio-economic development and will be able to solve their serious balance-of-payment problems,
Convinced that the solution of the energy problems would not by itself solve the whole set of difficulties facing the world economy,

Bearing in mind that the world economic crisis is intensifying further, which is manifested by a substantial deceleration in world economic activity and growth, a growing imbalance in international payments, high levels of unemployment and inflation, a sharp deterioration in the terms of trade of many developing countries, growing burdens of external indebtedness of the developing countries, and insecurity and insufficiency of food supplies,
Noting with regret that a considerable part of energy consumption is absorbed by the arms race,
Considering the role that Parliaments can and do play in solving the pressing problems that afflict the world economy, especially the economies of the developing countries,

1. Affirms that all nations have a vital interest in co-operating in the field of energy and its transport, on the basis of mutually beneficial arrangements, and in engaging freely in a reasonable and fair trade in energy products and technologies;
2. Emphasizes the need for consumers to take all possible steps to improve the efficiency of energy use;

3. Calls upon the industrialized countries, OPEC and those other countries which are in a position to do so to support all efforts, including those of the international institutions, to help the developing countries solve their energy problems;
4. Calls upon all countries to concentrate on the development of indigenous energy resources;
5. Calls upon all countries to recognize the magnitude and gravity of the energy crisis, and to pool all their technical knowledge with a view to achieving self-sufficiency in energy;

6. Calls upon Parliaments and Governments to adopt concrete and immediate measures to assist both in the mobilization of the energy resources of the developing countries through transfers of modern technologies facilitating the more effective utilization of conventional as well as new and renewable sources of energy, and in the creation in the developing countries of scientific and technological potentials, as well as the expansion of the process of the transfer of technology among the developing countries themselves;

7. Calls upon Parliaments and Governments to work for a thorough analysis of the ways of improving the situation of the oil-importing developing countries, with a view to supplying them with energy on stable and priority bases in response to their growing economic requirements and in accordance with the bilateral agreements concluded;

8. Proposes that there be a comprehensive co-operation effort among nations to minimize the environmental problems of the development and use of energy resources, including the problem of nuclear waste management;
9. Calls on Parliaments and Governments:
(a) To take up urgently and effectively the questions of raw materials, energy, trade and development, together with monetary and financial questions, in the context of the global negotiations;
(b) To grant priority, in the context of the global negotiations, to the proposal for the establishment of a world energy plan aimed at:

- Rationalizing oil consumption by the application of a system that would enable the waste of an exhaustible resource to be avoided and would promote an oil conservation policy in the interest of the international community;
- Working towards the diversification of the world energy balance, taking into account the specific requirements of the developing countries;
- Making a particular effort for the long-term conservation of energy, and in particular oil, so as to ensure, more especially, regular and long-term supply to the developing countries;
- Harnessing and developing the other conventional and non-conventional, renewable and non-renewable sources of energy;
- Intensifying the development of those energy sources whose use leads to an improvement of the environment through the recycling of urban, forest and animal waste and industrial waste;
- Establishing a plan of action to solve the problems of the oil-importing developing countries as regards energy supply and its financing;
10. Recommends that:

(a) A credit mechanism be established, based on the principles of voluntary choice and mutual benefit, commensurate with the real needs of the developing countries and for the purpose of financing research and exploitation concerning all sources of energy, and to facilitate research on the conversion from oil to other existing sources of energy where appropriate;

(b) The developed countries participate in the programme for the production of new and renewable sources of energy in the developing countries, bearing in mind the actual needs and interests of the receiving countries, and with full respect for these countries' national programmes, plans, priorities and decisions concerning development;
(c) The technology required for the exploitation of those alternative energy sources be transferred on advantageous terms to the developing countries and adapted by them for peaceful uses;

(d) Alternative energy sources be developed in the technologically advanced countries in order to balance energy consumption and guarantee a more substantial supply of oil to the developing countries;

11. Calls upon Parliaments and Governments to give active support to the United Nations and other international organizations in their activities directed towards strengthening and making concrete use of the existing possibilities and towards broadening the potential possibilities for international co-operation in the field of energy;
12. Urges Parliaments:

(a) To reaffirm the inalienable right of States to self-determination and to full and permanent sovereignty, in accordance with the principles of international law, over their natural resources and economic activities, especially the exploitation and marketing of their energy resources;

(b) To adopt whatever measures are necessary to co-operate with the developing countries that are importers of energy and manufactured goods, by transferring additional financial and technological resources so they can explore, use and develop the conventional energy resources that exist in their territories;

(c) To co-operate towards the implementation of the Programme of Action adopted by the United Nations Conference on New and Renewable Sources of Energy held at Nairobi in August 1981 for better utilization of existing energy resources, by making specific arrangements for transferring the most recent technology and financing other possible energy sources that will benefit the developing countries, while ensuring in all cases that every external technological acquisition is assimilated at the earliest possible date;

(d) To acknowledge the important role that new and renewable energy sources can play in solving the developing countries' energy problems by means of a gradual and ordered evolution of the world energy economy, recognizing at the same time that conventional energy resources should continue to be the short- and medium- term energy base for development in the developing countries;

(e) To reaffirm the right of States to supervise and control foreign investments in their territories and to guarantee that the activities of multinational corporations are in harmony with the host nation's priorities for socio-economic development, national values and laws;

(f) To promote effectively co-operation among nations to effect transfer of sufficient resources and technology to achieve economic development and progress in developing countries, giving special attention to the particular problems and needs of the least developed, most seriously affected and other special categories of developing countries as recognized by the United Nations;
13. Calls upon Parliaments and Governments:

(a) To support the establishment and implementation of a new world economic order that would ensure just and equitable exchange between the producers of raw materials, including energy, and the producers of manufactured goods;

(b) To regulate the conditions in which multinational oil corporations operate in the Third World so as to prevent new colonial dependence and exploitation, and to effect a rapid transfer of oil technology;
(c) To look with the utmost sense of urgency at the non-energy sources of inflation and recession in their national economies with a view to effecting remedial changes;
(d) To facilitate access by developing countries to research and new technology developed by national and multinational oil corporations in the area of alternative energy;

14. Urges Parliaments and Governments to give consideration to the conclusion of agreements seeking equitable ratios between the prices of the main commodities-raw materials, energy, farm-food produce and manufactured goods- which, based on recognition of the sovereign right of countries over their resources and economic activity, should reduce to the minimum the influence of monopolies on the market and reflect the cost and utility of the products, be remunerative for producers and equitable for purchasers, eliminate excessive price fluctuations on international markets and protect the purchasing power of the raw-material-exporting developing countries against the erosion generated by inflationist processes;
15. Calls upon Parliaments and Governments to exert efforts:
(a) For research and the rational exploitation of energy sources to be carried out in conformity with national plans and priorities;

(b) For the success of the United Nations Conference for the Promotion of International Co-operation in the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy, which is to enable the developing countries to gain the fullest possible access to technology for the production of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes which would contribute to their speedier economic and social development and the creation of an atmosphere of mutual understanding and co-operation among all States;

(c) For the establishment of an international agency for the development and exchange of new technology in the field of renewable sources of energy in order to assist in particular the countries of the South;
16. Recommends the formation and implementation at the national level of a comprehensive energy plan and policy aimed at:

(a) Surveying all national energy sources which can be economically mobilized in the medium- and the long-term, with a view to determining conventional and non-conventional sources and renewable and non-renewable sources;
(b) Giving priority to research into and exploitation of these sources in future development plans;
(c) Elaborating a policy for the optimal use of available energy on the basis of studies concerning energy supply and demand according to the economic sectors and between urban and rural areas;
(d) Researching, applying and adapting advanced technology in this field and at all levels of production, transport, distribution and consumption;
(e) Establishing institutes for research and training of specialized personnel in the field of energy;
(f) Increasing research and financing to solve the growing environmental problems of energy production;
(g) Promoting the conservation of energy and stimulating the saving thereof;
17. Stresses the importance of regional co-operation in the field of energy with the following objectives:
(a) Exploitation and development of different energy sources among neighbouring countries;
(b) Promotion of energy trade among countries in the same area;

(c) Promotion of technical co-operation, the sharing of training facilities, the exchange of experts and information, joint research and development programmes, mutually beneficial consultancy and related measures for the manufacture of the necessary machinery and apparatus for the production and transformation of energy;
(d) Establishment of specialized regional institutes in the field of research into the different energy sources;
18. Notes with satisfaction the existence of the following initiatives:
(a) The proposal of some OPEC member countries to create an institution for the development of the Third World;

(b) The proposal by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that the oil-producing countries and all the industrial countries form a 'Joint Fund for Energy and Development' with contributions proportional to the increases in oil prices and the inflation exported by the industrial countries; this Fund would be used to help developing countries which import oil or manufactured goods to carry out their development and meet their energy requirements;

(c) The proposal by the President of the Movement of Non-Aligned Countries, Fidel Castro, to devote no less than $300 billion as transfer of resources in real terms to developing countries during the 1980s;
(d) The proposal of President Lopez Portillo of Mexico for the establishment of a World Energy Plan;

(e) The recommendations of the Brandt Commission Report which emphasizes the need for an early and constructive dialogue between the developed and developing countries on the global economic problems affecting both.
