DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Street:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this legislation is to implement the changes in the application of the coal export levy introduced in last year's Budget-one of the many changes that the Government has made to coal levies in recent years. This time it is to extend the application of this tax, at a rate of $1 a tonne, to coals previously exempt. This will apply mainly to steaming coals but also to some low quality coking coals. Given the increased profitability of steaming coal ventures in recent years, the Opposition supports this measure as we believe that the Australian public should receive some return from the development of our natural resources. The Opposition, though, does not support the form of this tax-the way in which it is structured, the way in which it is continually being changed, and in fact the Government's whole ad hoc approach to taxation of the coal industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Since its introduction in 1975, the coal export levy has been changed five times despite a commitment by the Government to remove the levy entirely. In 1976 the then Treasurer, the present Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) announced that the levy would be phased out over a three-year period. During this time the Government changed the rates twice but the levy remained. Once again, as we have seen on many occasions, the Government failed to honour its commitments. Two years after breaking this promise-that is, in last year's Budget-the Government announced that it was 'no longer considered appropriate' to phase out the levy. Those were the Treasurer's words-'no longer considered appropriate'.

The industry had to wait two years before it was told what was going to happen to the levy. Now we see the application of the levy being extended. This ad hoc approach to policy is absurd. The coal industry is Australia's largest mineral export industry and is currently going through a new phase of development. It needs and deserves a consistent approach to policy and in particular a more predictable taxation policy. The industry should have a tax regime which does not change simply in line with the Government's revenue needs. Not only is the levy system unacceptable because of its many changes but also it is indiscriminate in its application. It fails to take into account the profitability or cost structure of a venture. It is important to recognise that there are long lead times involved in bringing a coal mine to production.

How are potential producers supposed to plan for a mine and mining development when the tax regime is unpredictable, indiscriminate and changes at the whim of the Government? This problem arises not only at the Federal level; the State governments are guilty of the same behaviour, but on a far worse scale. In recent years we have seen a proliferation of State taxes, royalties, excess freight rates, up front charges, et cetera, most of which are not economically sound and certainly do nothing to provide consistency in policy. Current taxation arrangements are not satisfactory.

The coal industry should have a tax regime which permits the economic potential of this industry to be realised while also providing a fair return to the Australian public. One means of doing this is through the introduction of a resource rent tax, or tax over and above company tax, as advocated by the Opposition and other bodies in this nation, such as the Federal Treasury, the Government's interdepartmental committee on economic policy and, of course, most leader writers in the country.
For this reason the Opposition will be moving the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the legislation:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give this Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the existing coal export levies are indiscriminate and calls upon the Government to introduce legislation to abolish the coal export duty and replace it with a resource rent tax which takes into account the real level of costs and profits'.

We will not oppose this legislation if the levy system is the only way of ensuring some return to the Australian people. But the Government must wake up to the reality of the situation and replace this draconian tax system with a properly structured resources tax. That is a far preferable system to flat rate levies. It would apply only to highly profitable ventures and not discriminate against high-cost producers. The amount of tax paid would be a function of a project's profitability. Certainly there are two levy rates; $3.50 and $1 a tonne depending on the quality of the coal and the type of mining operation. But the same rate applies within each category of coal irrespective of profitability although rates of return within the industry vary considerably.

The figures for 1978-79 show that the rate of return of funds employed in that year range from 25.9 per cent to a negative rate. The coal levy has imposed a major burden on those marginal producers at the bottom of this range. Under a profit-related tax these operations would pay no tax of this kind. Such a tax would also take into account the fact that costs are high in the early years of developing a mine. In these years when a high cash flow is needed to service debt commitments little or no tax would be payable because of the large capital expenditures incurred. But in latter years, once the major production costs have been written off, the Australian people would share in the benefits if profits proved to be of an exceptionally high order. It is only reasonable that companies should pay more than just company tax when a project has been operating for long enough to write off its capital costs and when it starts to make large profits, particularly if profits occur as a result of changes in world commodity prices or unforeseen changes which virtually bestow a very high opportunity value on the product. After all, the ownership of Australia's resources is vested in the Crown. The right to mine deposits is given to a company by the state. It is therefore reasonable that resource projects be treated differently for tax purposes than, say, a manufacturing business to which the state makes no contribution whatsoever.

Another reason for introducing such a tax is to maximise the benefits flowing to Australia from coal production, given the high level of foreign ownership in the industry. A recent study by Dr M. Folie from the Shell Company of Australia estimates that the present level of foreign ownership of the steaming coal industry is 38 per cent and he predicts that this will rise to 59 per cent over the next 10 years. In the case of coking coal he estimates that it is already as high as 60 per cent. Because of this high level of foreign ownership, profits earned by many companies in the industry are repatriated to parent companies overseas. If the companies involved were Australian the bulk of the profits would be retained in this country. In the light of this, if the benefits from developing Australian resources are to remain in Australia a resource rent tax should be introduced.

The need for a new tax regime is particularly evident at the moment given the new phase of development that our coal industry has entered, at least with respect to steaming coal. Australia currently exports about 39 million tonnes of coking coal a year and over 9 million tonnes of steaming coal. In the case of steaming coal, this compares with exports of only 3 million tonnes in 1976-77. So the figure has risen by 300 per cent in just a few years. Although estimates of future coal demand vary considerably, a recent study by the Department of Trade and Resources estimates that steaming coal exports will grow to 30 million to 40 million tonnes in 1985 and 50 million to 70 million tonnes in 1990. In the case of coking coal, the Department estimates exports of between 48 million and 55 million tonnes by 1985 and 50 million to 60 million tonnes by 1990. In other words, between 1976 and 1990 we should see the Australian steaming coal industry develop on such a scale as to rival in size and in volume the coking coal industry which, of course, started 15 years earlier.

There are, of course, factors operating to limit the growth of coal exports in general. Increased competition can be expected from South Africa, Canada, China, Alaska and other parts of the United States of America. Also, stable international oil prices have slowed the movement away from oil-based energy. Domestic factors such as insufficient infastructure-transport and port facilities-will also act to limit expansion in this industry. Despite all this the industry will continue to expand, particularly in steaming coal. This has already been reflected in recent steaming coal price increases. The average price for steaming coal exported from New South Wales increased from $28 a tonne in July 1980 to $38 a tonne in July 1981 and to recent contract prices of between $42 to $48 a tonne.

If coal prices continue to increase the ensuing profits should be shared between the producers and the public. If they do not, a resource rent tax would take this into account. It would therefore levy no tax, unlike the existing levy system which levies a tax whether or not companies are in a profit situation. If large profits are to be earned in the coal industry, in many cases by foreign companies, some mechanism must be established to share the benefits. A future Labor government would certainly seek to apply a resource rent tax to the coal industry. The tax would be carefully designed in consultation with the industry so that the objectives of such a tax would be met without some of the distortional effects which can arise from taxes which are ill-designed or hastily implemented.

Some sections of the coal industry can afford to pay more than just company tax and should be obliged to do so. No sensible person believes in penalising companies to the point where development is stymied or where exploration is discouraged. What is needed is a sensible approach by both industry and government to determine the appropriate nature and incidence of tax. We believe a resource rent tax is the appropriate mechanism. For the Commonwealth to vacate the field of mineral taxation is only to encourage a lack of uniformity. As we have seen with the continuing proliferation of State taxes, in the end the possibility is that the goose that laid the golden egg will be killed off by the greed, particularly of the States. The whole prospect of the establishment of a resource rent tax has, of course, been cast under a cloud by the fact that, with a few profit centres excluded, the industry is not in a position to make a substantial contribution because of the taxes levied in freight rates, up-front royalties and the like. Before very much longer we are going to have to get to the stage where the Commonwealth says to the States that if they continue to proliferate taxes on mining, the Commonwealth will reduce reimbursements to the States by the amount of any new mining taxes. The alternative will be a hotch potch of State taxes. The opportunity for uniform Commonwealth mineral taxation will be diminished. This will be bad for Australia, bad for the mineral industry , bad for the coal mining industry and, of course, bad for the public revenue. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give this Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the existing coal export levies are indiscriminate and calls upon the Government to introduce legislation to abolish the coal export duty and replace it with a resource rent tax which takes into account the real level of costs and profits.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia's coal reserves are considerable, but are only about 4 per cent of world reserves and consist of about 18,000 million to 25,000 million tonnes of recoverable coal. Although we have only 4 per cent of world reserves, at the moment we control 18 to 20 per cent of the world trade in export coal.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that any major Australian export-based resource industry should be based effectively on three criteria. It should provide for a gross profit and certainly not return an operating loss. It should offer maximum employment opportunity. It should also make a significant contribution to government revenue by way of taxes, levies and, if necessary, some form of public participation, to ensure that non-renewable resources are not consumed without an adequate return to the Australian people. Labor, when in government, perceived that this was not happening. Thus, in 1975, a $6 per tonne levy was imposed upon high quality coking coal. That situation was changed by the present Government in 1976 when the levy was reduced to $4 per tonne and then, in 1977, by a further 50c to $3.50. We had a further change in 1979 when the Budget provided for the retention of that figure for existing open cut mines of a depth of less than 60 metres, but reduced it to $1 for new open cut mines, underground mines and existing open cut mines of a depth of more than 60 metres. We have now moved to a situation in which the $1 levy will be extended to steaming coal.

Although the Opposition-I will explain the reasons in a moment-would much prefer a resource based rent tax, it certainly would not oppose, in the absence of such a tax, the imposition of a $1 levy on steaming coal. However, although this Government will not admit it, a tonnage levy presents major problems. I will give two examples to explain what I mean. In the 1981 calendar year the Utah Development Corporation, despite industrial disputes, made an after-tax profit of $132.6m. Utah is a large open cut mining operator in the Bowen Basin of central Queensland. In the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Les Johnson), which adjoins my own, there is a small underground mine, South Bulli, which is run by the Bellambi Coal Co. Ltd. In the year in which Utah made its $132m profit, Bellambi Coal Co., which is now owned mainly by Shell, returned, amazingly, a $5.8m operating net loss.

This levy is discriminatory. Utah paid $3.50 per tonne, and Bellambi Coal Co. paid $1 per tonne even though the latter suffered a $5.8m loss. Labor's proposal is that a resource rent tax be imposed after company tax has been paid, on a project by project basis if necessary. The principle is very simple. It is applied at a certain threshold percentage of profit to capital investment and thus is aimed at giving a viable return to the investor.

Let us compare the return to federal revenue from Utah that would have been achieved in 1981 if a resource rent tax at a threshold level of 15 per cent and, for purposes of comparison, 100 per cent thereafter, rather than the current levy, had been imposed. Let me again explain, put simply, a resource rent tax can be applied at a predetermined threshold percentage of profits to fixed capital investment. Such a tax allows a viable return to investors. It can then be applied to company or project profits above that figure according to a predetermined percentage. Let us, then, compare the return to federal revenue from Utah at the current tonnage levy with what would have been raised if a resource rent tax had been imposed at a threshold level of 15 per cent and 100 per cent thereafter. For this purpose I ask that the relevant figures from the annual report of the Utah Development Corporation be incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It can be seen that in 1981 Utah's net profit amounted to $132.6m and that $53m was contributed to federal revenue by way of export levy. The fixed capital investment of the company in its five coal mines in the Bowen Basin of Queensland and in port facilities at Hay Point totals approximately $620m. Fifteen per cent of $620m is $93m. That is the level of after-company tax profitability at which the resource rent tax would operate in this hypothetical exercise. However, as the export levy would have been replaced by the resource rent tax mechanism, of the $53m raised from Utah in 1981 by the levy, $24m would have been paid in company tax and $29m would have been added to profits. So the relevant figures would then have been: $169.9m paid in company tax and company profitability of $161.6m. That figure is $68.6m above the threshhold at which the resource rent tax would have commenced. The total payment to federal revenue, including corporate income tax, branch profits tax, coal resource levy, excise tax and resource rent tax would have amounted in 1981 to $256.7m, compared with the $217m, including the coal export levy, that was actually paid. Thus, if in 1981 a resource rent tax had been applied to Utah at the threshhold levels that I have mentioned, instead of the coal export levy, $ 39.5m extra in federal revenue would have been collected from Utah.

SPEECH.PARA: The resource rent tax has the advantage, as I have shown, of not discriminating against smaller companies and underground mines. However, it has the disadvantage of being applied after State royalties and charges, taxes, rail freight and so on, have been imposed. There is also the possibility that transfer pricing will be resorted to and that companies will sell for less than world market prices. We can overcome transfer pricing arrangements and attempts at underpricing on the world market by resorting to the fixing of pricing parameters, as even this Government once attempted to do, although not so successfully as did my late and great predecessor, Rex Connor.

In order to combat underpricing and transfer pricing, we could refuse to grant export licences unless such pricing parameters were met. But a greater problem is the burgeoning size of State charges. I point out to the House the increasing nature of the problem.

Let us consider the position as it applies to Utah. In 1977 the Queensland Government collected $20.8m from that company in royalties. By 1981 the figure increased to only $30m. But by 1981 the cost of rail freight had risen to $82m. The figure for 1979 was $47.5m. Utah's total payments in 1977 to the State of Queensland amounted to $23m but by 1981 had risen to $116.7m. In contrast, total federal taxes had only grown from $182m in 1977 to $217m in 1981. The return from the coal export levy had actually declined by $1.8m to $53m. In fact, the coal export levy returned to federal revenue from Utah last year was $53m compared with a total of $116.7m paid to the Queensland Government. It was actually less than the $82m that was paid to the Queensland Government in freight charges.

An ideal arrangement would be for the States to reach agreement with the Commonwealth to waive State charges and royalties, except perhaps for rail freight, to allow the imposition of a Federal resource rent tax, which is, of course, non-discriminatory, on a project by project basis, and with adequate reimbursement from the Commonwealth to the State governments involved. In regard to coal production, in 1981 Australia produced 92 million tonnes of saleable coal and exported 51 million tonnes-23.3 million tonnes from New South Wales and 27.7 million tonnes from Queensland. That is a very high export percentage. The Joint Coal Board predicts that by 1990 New South Wales alone could be exporting 75 million tonnes, at a high level prediction, or around 50 million tonnes at a low level prediction. I do not think that high level will be reached. There will be problems with port construction and transport, particularly between the southern fields of New South Wales and the Port Kembla loader. There possibly will be a world recession and falling oil prices; Japan will import less than expected. Nevertheless, as the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) has said, development will still be considerable, particularly in the steaming coal area, for domestic and export purposes.

In this situation it really is not good enough to have State governments and the companies themselves making the decisions to develop a new mine. It was because of this truth that in 1979 we decided there was a real need to expand the concept of the New South Wales Joint Coal Board into a Commonwealth coal authority which could be established with the States through a national fuel and energy commission and the States' statutory coal authorities. It could impose a policy of rational exploitation of Australia's coal resources with particular regard to the limited resources of certain types of coal, domestic requirements for coal and the balanced development of our coal exports.

I conclude on this note: There is a problem in some areas and in regard to some qualities of coal. The southern fields of New South Wales have an economically recoverable reserve of about 1.8 billion tonnes. At the exploitation rate anticipated for use of stage one of the new Port Kembla coal loader and some mild expansion in the local steel industry, the field would be eliminated within 75 or 80 years. If there were an exponential growth rate of 3 per cent that period would come back to 45 years and if there were an exponential growth rate of 6 per cent we could have less than 30 years supply of coal in the New South Wales southern fields, which of course supply not only the export market but also the great steel industry at Port Kembla which employs over 35,000 people. Certainly I do not want to put an anti-development case against the coal industry but there is a need to rationalise the development, particularly with regard to certain qualities of coking coal, and the possible deficiencies of certain quality coals in areas adjacent to the steel industry, to ensure that there is a long term future not only for the coal exporting industry but also for that other great and even more employment-intensive area, the domestic steel industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The provisions of the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill came into effect close to seven months ago; that is, at 8 p .m. on 18 August 1981-Budget night. In effect we are ritualistically dealing with this matter. The purpose of the Bill is to impose an export duty of $1 per tonne on black coal previously exempt from export duty. Up to now a duty has operated on exports of coking coal at a rate of either $3.50 per tonne or $1 per tonne, and these arrangements continue to exist. The coal concerned was measured in terms of its quality; that was the differentiating factor for this duty. Steaming coal was exempt but now the Government believes the industry is more buoyant and is capable of withstanding this new imposition. Of course steaming coal is in demand more now because of the increase in the price of oil that occurred in 1979. The Government has an entirely different view from the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume), who seems to believe that there will be some kind of inevitable decline in the coal industry. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), in his second reading speech on this Bill, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Because of changes in the world market for energy resources and the consequential strengthening of export demand for steaming coal the Government decided that there was no longer any reason to differentiate between coking coal and steaming coal in the application of the export duty.

It seems to me that the honourable member for Macarthur was wrong on a number of fronts. There has been very considerable growth in the coal industry in New South Wales. It is as plain as a pike staff that there is no lack of confidence on the part of the private entrepreneurial people involved. They have never been so enthusiastic about ripping into this great inevitable bonanza. It is totally absurd for the honourable member to put the proposition with which we were confronted tonight. Almost everything he said was totally absurd and without foundation. I would like him to put to the honourable member for Barton (Mr Bradfield) or to any Liberal member precariously holding his seat in Sydney that a coal loader should be built in Botany Bay, so contaminating it, in the face of all the environmental reports made about this matter. Yet he doggedly goes on with that kind of ridiculous contention.

Far from lacking confidence in New South Wales, the coal mining people are spending money as though it is going out of fashion. In 1979-80 capital expenditure in the industry in New South Wales totalled $198m. In the next year it was $480m-a peculiar lack of confidence, as I see it! In fact, more than double what was spent in the previous year was spent in 1980-81. The biggest rate of growth was in the northern and western areas of the State. The planned expenditure for 1981-82 is $1,140m. It is going up by leaps and bounds. That is more than twice the actual expenditure in 1980-81 and almost six times the expenditure of 1979-80. Honourable members do not have to take my word for this. These figures come from the report of the Joint Coal Board and I do not think anybody would call them into dispute. As at June 1981 employment in the New South Wales coal mining industry stood at 19,867 persons, 12.4 per cent more than the previous year. The post-war peak in 1952 was only 20,802, so we are nudging that figure now.

Yet the honourable member for Macarthur says that this industry is going out of fashion and that the Wran Government has eroded confidence. One could not point to any other industry in all Australia over the whole of its history as having such an incredible, meteoric rise and expansion rate. Production in that year totalled 48.1 million tonnes, up 12.6 per cent over the previous year. Exports from New South Wales were up from 21,870 million tonnes to 23,710 million tonnes , an increase of 8.4 per cent. That is a record for all time, limited only by coal loading facilities-nothing else. That problem is being dealt with as effectively as possible.

It seems to me that a wrong emphasis is being brought to bear by the honourable member for Macarthur. He has made some disparaging remarks about the idea of a resource tax, which was put forward by the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) and the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) as an alternative to the levy arrangement which is the subject of this Bill. But a levy represents a direct addition to costs rather than the sharing up of the profit. The merit of a resource rent tax, if applied on a project by project basis, is that it will operate as a levy on that portion of profit which is above the level necessary to maintain the viability of the project having regard to the risks involved. It is an eminently sensible proposition. In effect, it is a profit that could be had in respect to a very lucrative return. The arrangement that operates at present is a very insecure way for an industry to approach its entrepreneurial efforts.

I was impressed by a report which has recently come to hand. The report, which is dated January 1982 and comes from the Illawarra and Macarthur Group of Local Government Councils Research Committee into the Coal Mining Industry, was submitted to the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce which is examining the present state and prospects of the Australian export coal industry with particular reference to its contribution to the economy. The report, emanating from the source I have mentioned, naturally concerns itself with the problems affecting the coal mining industry in the areas represented by me-some of the biggest underground mines in Australia are in my electorate at Corrimal, Bulli, Helensburg, Coalcliff and quite a number of others-the honourable member for Cunningham and the honourable member for Macarthur. The general contention in the submission is to the effect that governments ought to be looking at the problems that are created as a result of the coal mining industry and should be making some contribution, through levies of the type we are discussing tonight, so that they can be alleviated.

I am not one who normally contends that money raised in an area should be spent on that area. I believe that all Australians should share benefits from the exploitation of Australian resources. But when an industry such as the coal mining industry has highly deleterious effects on a community and sets that community behind other communities in terms of environmental factors, road and bridge problems and so on, there seems to me to be a lot of sense in upholding the claim made in this submission that some special return should be made to the areas concerned from the proceeds of the industry. I want to put that kind of case here tonight.

The significance of the mining industry in the South Coast mining areas which were the subject of the report is demonstrated by the fact that raw production in 1978-79-the last year mentioned in the report-was 16.373 million tonnes, close to half of which was exported. So in the first place we are talking about a very great export industry. The region is making a substantial contribution to the wellbeing of the nation. It is very interesting to note a table in the submission entitled 'Distribution of Coal Industry Revenue 1979-80' which sets out the deployment of revenue from this massive industry to workers in the industry, State and Federal government services and so on. State taxes and profits account for 15.6 per cent of the revenue in the region, Federal Government taxes account for 15 per cent and poor old local government gets only 1.5 per cent of the deal. The table indicates that company profits were at the surprisingly low figure of 3.6 per cent of all the revenue raised in the industry. But I really want to contrast the low figure that is returned to local government, which has to bear the brunt of all of the deleterious effects of the industry, with the comparatively high return to both the State and Federal governmental areas.

Professor D. Barnett, the Associate Professor of Mineral Economics at the Macquarie University, said that in 1979-80 total profits from New South Wales coal exports averaged $12.32 a tonne, of which the New South Wales Government received $5.38 a tonne, the Federal Government $5.18 a tonne, local government 52c a tonne and the coal companies $1.24 a tonne. Once again this demonstrates the infinitesimal proportion of revenue returned to local government. The report refers to large disparities in the valuation of land compared to adjoining properties. Land values varied from 3.74 per cent to 43 per cent. This relates to colliery land as against land used for other purposes. So local government cannot even pick up revenue from that source. I believe that the objective ought to be to marry the revenue from the coal export levy to the solution of problems created by the coal industry in areas where coal is extracted. My remarks certainly do not apply just to my own area in New South Wales though I have used it as an example. I believe the same kind of treatment is necessary in respect of many deprived areas of Newcastle.

The honourable member for Macarthur, who spoke a short time ago, is well known for being the spokesman for the road hauliers group in New South Wales. He could not give a damn whether the highly capitalised railway system of this State, which is a great instrumentality financed by the taxpayers of this country, pays or not. He does not care because he is generously supported in his election campaigns by the road hauliers. He is there to speak for them and I know he does it very effectively. But the fact of the matter is that we just cannot have a decent community when there are coal trucks running through the streets in a highly damaging and dangerous way, as happens in many of these areas. The city of Wollongong has almost been ruined as a result of this kind of activity. Accidents are the order of the day. Masses of people have been injured, maimed and killed. The honourable member for Macarthur believes that the truck hauliers should be aided and abetted and given unrestricted licence to continue. He gives the impression that it is not a good policy to get coal trucks off the road. Of course it is. The sensible thing is to do in this country what is being done in many countries, that is to carry coal on the people's railway to ensure that we get the best possible return from that kind of activity.

In my electorate new loading facilities have been erected for the purpose of facilitating the movement of coal by rail. Regrettably coal often has to be stored in unsightly storage bins. We need to use some of the money made by the industry to create a better environment. The same position applies in areas such as Wollongong and Port Kembla which are represented by my colleague the honourable member for Cunningham. An enormous coal loader is being constructed in his electorate. A coal loader is an ugly development no matter how nicely the problem is handled. There is a great need for environmental factors to be considered. As a consequence of this Bill the Government intends to reef another $130m out of the coal mining industry each year. I think it is reasonable that some of this money be given to areas which are suffering so adversely. According to all the well informed people in government and industry this prosperous industry is going to become more buoyant in the future than it ever has been in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The purpose of the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill is to enact the Customs tariff alterations introduced into the Parliament on 18 August 1981 by the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Proposals (1981) which formally proposed with effect from 8 p.m. on that day an export duty of $1 per tonne on black coal previously exempt from the export duty . As the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) has indicated, the Opposition is moving an amendment which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give this Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the existing coal export levies are indiscriminate and calls upon the Government to introduce legislation to abolish the coal export duty and replace it with a resource rent tax which takes into account the real level of costs and profits.'

The Opposition has been consistent in campaigning around the question of a resource rent tax. It pleases me to know that increasing numbers of people are becoming convinced of the appropriateness of that type of approach. What I have been concerned about is the marked difference between the rhetoric and the substance of this Government's attitude towards levies on mineral production and , in particular, the Government's record on this levy. The honourable member for Blaxland indicated that in 1976 the present Government gave an undertaking that it would eliminate the coal export levy over a period of three years. Of course, like most of its undertakings that one was never honoured. In 1976-77 the total revenue derived from the export levy was $121.3m. In 1977-78 it declined to $100 .2m. During that year it was announced in the Budget that the rates would be reduced, and they were.

In 1978-79 the revenue derived was $93.5m, so it had declined again. Again, during that year, an announcement was made at the time of the Budget that the levies would be abolished from 30 June 1979. Again, that undertaking was not honoured. In 1979-80, the revenue derived from the coal export levy again declined to $90.7m. From 1 November 1979 the $3.50 rate was reduced to $1 per tonne for underground mines and new open cuts which came into operation after 30 June 1980. In 1980-81 the total revenue derived from the coal export levy declined again to $84.9m.

Prior to 18 August 1981 the levy applied to coking coal only. It was applied at two rates-$3.50 a tonne for the higher quality coking coal, which was mined from open cut mines that operated at less than 60 metres below the surface, and $1 a tonne for all other coking coal. However, since 18 August-this legislation is designed to give effect to the change on that day-the $1 per tonne levy is to apply as well to steaming coal. It is estimated that in 1981-82-during the current year-as a result of those adjustments the revenue to be derived from the coal export levy will increase to $115m. That includes the $10m which will be derived from the new levy. This assumes an increase in export tonnage of 17 per cent during the current year. It represents an increase of 35.5 per cent in the total revenue being derived from that levy.

It is interesting to note the contrast between undertakings that have been given by the Government on previous occasions and what in fact it has done. It is not my wish to defend the levy approach or the level at which that levy has been set. But during the debate when the original levy was introduced in 1975-it was fixed at $6 per tonne for high quality coking coal and $2 per tonne for lower quality coking coal-the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Adermann), who was the then Opposition spokesman on customs and excise, said:
We believe that this tax is the most retrograde tax perhaps in the whole of the Budget.
The honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe) interjected:
It is stopping development in the industry too.

He was referring to the coal mining industry. The attitude of the honourable member for Paterson, whose electorate does contain a large number of coal mining projects and employs a large number of coal miners, seems remarkable given that he is not participating in this debate. The words spoken by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) give an indication that his approach, like the approach of the honourable member for Paterson, is of one kind when in Opposition and another when in government. His contribution has been weak and largely platitudinous. In 1975 the honourable member for Fisher also said:
I appeal that the Government should . . . remove this tax forthwith.
The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) who was at that time the Leader of the National Country Party in Opposition said:
Above all, I do not believe in the philosophy of export taxes. They are retrograde taxes. They are a depressant against encouraging people to get into the export business.

I am concerned that levies of this kind are non-discriminatory. They are applied right across the board. It makes no difference whether the steaming coal which has been mined has been mined in a high cost, low profit project or whether it has been mined in one where the profits are higher. Of course, the lower profits are being made in the underground mines, many of which are increasingly becoming marginal. Underground mines are the largest employers of labour. There is no relationship at all between a levy of this kind and either the costs or the profits of any coal mining undertaking. Many of the coal mines producing steaming coal-mines to which this export levy will now apply-are marginal. For instance, at Camden, which is in the electorate of Macarthur, the suggestion that it be a requirement that all the coal be carried by road instead of rail brought an outcry from both the mining operators and the coal miners because the additional cost would place them in an awkward position and could bring about the closure of some of the marginal mines. In the Cessnock area, which is within my electorate, projects are under way at present. It is planned to mine deeper seams of steaming coal. They are essentially marginal projects and are yet to be proven. Millions of dollars have been invested in one project which still is to be proven. Despite that, this Government is imposing a tax which takes no account of the circumstances and the profitability of the mining ventures.

Earlier this month an announcement was made which indicated that Austen and Butta Ltd was now having a second look at its proposal to establish another underground steaming coal project in East Lithgow. Construction on that project was scheduled to start in the middle of this year. The total investment cost was to be $158m. It was proposed to export 3.1 million tonnes per year by 1989. The company indicated that recent increases in wages, rail freights and costs generally, which include this export levy on steaming coal, were among the factors which were causing it to have another look at that project. If that project does not go ahead, if those mines in the Cessnock area do not proceed and if those marginal mines in the Camden area close down and throw people out of employment as a result of additional costs being imposed by this Government, then this Government will have to take the responsibility for it. It does not matter very much what the honourable member for Macarthur says in connection with it. He indicated a very weak attitude towards this question. If he is genuine he is a latter day spokesman for the coal miners in the Camden area and in the Macarthur electorate. If he were genuine about the matter he would do the same sort of thing as the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) does-he would cross the floor and vote against this legislation. But of course when the chips are down he is dictated to by the Government on whose side he sits, despite the fact that the decision that he makes in this place may well be against the interests of the coal miners in his area.

The reason given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) in his second reading speech for imposing this duty on lower valued coal, principally steaming coal, which had been exempted from this duty, was that because of changes in the world market for energy resources and the consequential strengthening of export demand for steaming coal, the Government has decided that there is no longer any reason to differentiate between coking coal and steaming coal. What in fact the Government said, despite its rhetoric to the contrary, was that if there is some taxation revenue to be obtained by ripping off part of the profits of steaming coal miners, whether they are high cost or low cost producers, this Government will step in and do something about it. What a remarkable contrast this is with the statement that the Leader of the National Country Party made in 1975 when the National Country Party was one of the coalition parties in opposition. Referring to the Labor Government's proposal, he said:

But no, if there are any prospects that someone will have a boom or success this Government will clamp down as hard as it can. I am just staggered that the Government is doing it to the coal mining industry.

Where does he stand now in connection with this proposal and what attitude is he adopting in relation to this levy that is being imposed? The timing of this proposal is absolutely absurd. In the first place there is a world oil glut and this is having an effect on steaming coal prices and the effectiveness with which we can market our steaming coal. Increasing volumes of steaming coal are coming from the west coast of North America, from the Gulf area of North America and from South Africa, and all this steaming coal is going into those markets which we were hoping would be markets in which we would have a greater share. The Japanese are in the process now of providing finance, expertise and advice to China in order to develop the steaming coal deposits in China. The world steaming coal market is flat and there is every reason for us not to believe that the increased market and the higher prices that have been experienced over recent years will continue.

The amendment is in the terms that this type of indiscriminate levy, which will be imposed across the board, should be replaced by a resource rent tax. A resource rent tax would be discretionary, profit related and free of any distortionary impact on the industries and minerals upon which it is imposed. But because of the vacuum being created by this Government and its reluctance to introduce such an appropriately structured tax on excess profits made from resource development, the states are increasingly stepping in to fill the breach . For example, in the Northern Territory the bauxite royalties have been renegotiated. The Northern Territory Government has also considered levying a profit related royalty of 35 per cent on a pre-tax, net profit on various mineral development projects in the Northern Territory. The Queensland Government has increased the rail freights on the movement of minerals, particularly coal. There was also that $220m sweetener that was included in the winning bid for the prospecting rights in the Winchester South coal deposits in central Queensland. In Victoria there was an increase in the pipeline fees. Also the State Electricity Commission imposed increased charges. In New South Wales- reference has been made to this by others-there have been increases in rail freights. The proposed lease fee in New South Wales of 25c a tonne on coal through the new Kooragang Island coal loader will be based on a minimum throughput of 10 million tonnes. In Western Australia a tax arrangement has been established by agreement with the Ashton Joint Venturers under which the government will levy a 22.5 per cent profit related tax once profits reach a trigger level of $20m per annum. So the States are stepping in. The vacuum has been created by this Government. Until this Government takes a more sensible and more responsible attitude towards the whole question of the appropriateness of correctly structured tax on the profits being made on resource development, this situation will continue.

In conclusion I advise the Government and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that not only are they missing out on the opportunity to introduce an appropriately structured resource rent tax but also, because the States are stepping in to fill the vacuum, most of the levies, the charges, the extra freights, the additional fees and the extra royalties that are being imposed by the States, are costs which are applied before tax. This means that not only is the Commonwealth missing out on the possibility of a resource rent tax but also, because the States are stepping in to fill the vacuum, it is missing out on the correct share of company tax. How absurd and how indefensible. Increasingly, people are supporting the proposition of a resource rent tax. This proposition is being increasingly supported by resource developers themselves because they do not not know where the additional State charge, special tax, extra freight, levy or royalty will bubble up next. Of course mineral developers want something which is sensible and which is appropriately structured and which gives them reason to believe that they can be sure and secure about the future. They do not want new charges being thrown at them every week. I support the Opposition's amendment to the effect that this levy be abolished and replaced by an appropriate resource rent tax.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
