DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in relation to this proposition was more significant in what it concealed than in what it revealed. The purpose of this amending Bill, to which the Government has already given notice of an amendment which the Minister will move at the Committee stage, is to provide for additional tax-sharing grants and special allocations totalling $69m to New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland, and to provide for the payment of a fixed tax-sharing grant of $315.1m to the Northern Territory. Both of those provisions relate to the current year, 1981-82 .

SPEECH.PARA: I have said that the Treasurer's second reading speech was more remarkable for what it concealed than for what it revealed. This piece of legislation has an interesting background. The events which have led up to it illustrate probably better than many other developments the arrogant and cynical attitude that this Government has taken towards the States and the contempt which it shows for the States and their governments. Fundamental to the whole mess involving State grants and the formulas which are being applied and the volumes which are involved is the present Government's supposed new federalism. Many of the States were encouraged in the first place to support the concept of new federalism because they believed that the Commonwealth Government would be increasing the total value of assistance available to them. What in fact happened, of course, was that while untied grants and general revenue grants, were increased, specific purpose grants, special grants and capital grants were reduced to a greater extent. So in real terms the States are now worse off than they were in 1975-76 as a result of the last Budget of the Labor Government.

The income tax sharing arrangements which apply currently replaced the previous financial assistance grants in 1976-77. Prior to that, 33.6 per cent of the year 's personal income tax collections were provided for the States in untied grants , and, as a result of them being related to that year's taxation, the States could never be certain about the total amount that they would receive during any year. So the formula was changed in 1978-79 to relate it to the personal income tax collections of the previous year, and in that year the formula resulted in 39.87 per cent of personal income tax being granted to the States.

The States have been deliberately manipulated by the Fraser Government into a seriously disadvantaged position. While that was going on, the Government was also flagging the possibility that there would be a major switch from personal income tax to indirect taxes. It was also flagging the possibility that tax indexation would be applied consistently and continuously. If in fact those impressions had been realised, the States would have been in a position in which the personal income tax to which their grants were being related would have been increasing at a rate slower than that of other Commonwealth revenue. The States then were manipulated into a position in which they felt that other forms of taxation would be increasing more rapidly.

As a result of that the States, in their submission to the Commonwealth early in 1981, suggested that the base for the determination of those grants be either personal income tax or total tax, because they were concerned that the base for the income tax sharing arrangement would be continually eroded. The Commonwealth proposed, after a transition year in 1981-82, that the arrangements move to a total tax base. The standard percentage would be the State grants of 1981-82, which were based on 39.87 per cent of the personal income tax of the previous year, 1980-81, and that the 1981-82 grant would then be expressed as a percentage of total tax receipts in the previous year and that then would determine the percentage which would be applied for grants of that kind in subsequent years. Apparently the percentage has worked out to be 20.72 per cent.

Having got the States to accept and, in fact, to encourage the movement to a total tax base, the Government abandoned tax indexation. The result is, of course, that next year personal income tax collection, which had previously formed the basis for the allocation of State grants, will rise at a rate faster than any other area of taxation and will bring to the Commonwealth an additional $5,000m. The States will not share in that to the extent that they should.

The States were also conned by the Commonwealth Government as a result of the Premiers Conference which, we well remember, was held on 4 May 1981. This incident provides part of the background for the amending Bill which the House is now considering. We well remember on that occasion the Treasurer admitting that, with the concurrence of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), he had leaked a Cabinet decision which set an upper limit of a further $70m. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister publicly chortled and gloated about the way in which they had conned the States. That accounts for the fact that this legislation provides for the allocation of an additional $69m-very close to that upper limit to which the Treasurer and the Prime Minister failed to go, which would have represented an additional $70m for the States.

Of course, on that occasion, the States were extremely upset-even to the extent that the Liberal Premier of Western Australia was demanding the immediate resignation of the Treasurer. But the Treasurer was not the only person responsible for that decision. The Treasurer was not prepared to accept on his own shoulders the responsibility for that decision, and it became quite obvious that the Prime Minister was personally involved.

The specific background to these supplementary grants is related to the fact that total tax sharing grants, once determined, must then be allocated among the States. This is done on a weighted per capita basis. From 1976 to 1981 the weights used were the per capita relativities which applied in 1975-76. These relativities did not reflect any concept of fiscal equalisation but evolved basically through a process of historical accident. In fact, Russell Barton, in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 June last year, wrote:
According to Government officials, the proposed division of funds would redress the imbalance created by years of political patronage by the Federal Government towards the smaller States.
This is the fault of not just this Government; governments over a long period have created this imbalance as a result of the political patronage they showed those States.

Three years ago, as a result of that situation developing, the Commonwealth Grants Commission was charged with responsibility for determining a new and a fairer distribution of total general revenue grants. Its report was presented to the Parliament on 10 June last year and was considered by the Premiers Conference on 20 June. That report recommended the reallocation between the States of almost $300m of the total of the general revenue grants which were being made available to the States. New South Wales was supposed to receive an additional $118m; Victoria was supposed to receive an additional $68.2m; Queensland was supposed to receive an additional $108.3m. In fact, New South Wales will finish up receiving-this legislation gives effect to it-only $24.5m; Victoria will receive only $15m; and Queensland will receive only $20.5m, together with an additional once only grant of $9 million which is being made available to Queensland because of the adjustment that has been made in the estimation of the population base.

Between 1976-77 and 1979-80, the real value of the States' general revenue grants was maintained only by the guarantee arrangement linked to the formula that was applied by the Whitlam Government. The States found themselves in increasingly difficult circumstances because the Commonwealth was retreating from many areas in which it had previously been involved and at the same time leaving those responsibilities to the States without giving the States the financial capacity to see them through. Stage 2 of this supposed new federalism was to provide for the States to have discretion either to increase or to reduce the tax being applied in each of the States, depending upon their own discretion . Fortunately, up to the present, no State has passed the enabling legislation. In connection with the whole question of taxation policy and fiscal management, the States are showing themselves to be much more responsible than this Government. I indicated on a previous occasion that in this year alone total Commonwealth Government revenue will be $7,819 million higher in real terms than it was in the last Labor Budget and that total Commonwealth grants to the States will be down in real terms to the extent of $1,736m.

The arrangements contained within this legislation are not opposed by the Opposition. They give to those States which the Commonwealth Grants Commission had indicated were being underfunded in terms of an appropriate grants formula an additional $69m, when the amount of $70m was kept from them during the Premiers Conference in May of last year. There is concern on the part of the Opposition about the amendment, notice of which has been given and which presumably will be moved by the Treasurer at the Committee stage. I will have more to say about that amendment at that stage because I am not clear on a number of the details regarding the meaning and the impact of that amendment. If my concern is justified the Opposition will oppose that amendment, but at this stage the Opposition is in favour of this legislation which will give effect to the granting of the additional funds to those States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill which we are presently debating has considerable significance for the Northern Territory because it is this amendment which appropriates $315.1m for general revenue funds to the Northern Territory Government. Unlike those for the States, the financial arrangements that apply between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory are written down in a memorandum of understanding agreed to by the respective governments. General revenue assistance is one of the basic elements of Commonwealth assistance to the Northern Territory. The amount is analogous to a State's tax sharing entitlement and is determined by the formula laid down in the memorandum of understanding.

SPEECH.PARA: The present arrangements are very satisfactory and are quite clearly contributing to the solid growth the Northern Territory economy is undergoing at the moment. I do want to point out however that since the first meeting in 1977, determining the financial agreement between the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth-a meeting that I attended-it was made perfectly clear that as far as the Commonwealth was concerned, the special circumstances and the particular difficulties of the Northern Territory would be fully recognised and provided for in funding arrangements. I will return to this point later.

Ensuring a high level of funding for the Northern Territory is important for a number of reasons. The Northern Territory population base is too small to be able to collect enough revenue to provide services that are comparable to those enjoyed by other States. In addition, the Government must face extra costs in providing for residents in outlying and inaccessible areas. The money is essential if the Northern Territory is to promote growth and development and if we are to attract industry to the Territory. The end result of this, of course, will be a lessening of our dependence on Commonwealth funds. The fourth reason is that the Territory Government must provide for a large number of disadvantaged people, notably Aborigines.

Few people would disagree that the pace of development in the Northern Territory since self-government has been remarkable. We have been able to attract many people disillusioned with reduced opportunities in the south. The population of the Northern Territory has grown by as much as 7 per cent per annum, meaning that much of the Territory Budget has had to be devoted to the social infrastructure necessary to cope with such expansion. For the Northern Territory 1981 was a year of real achievement. Whilst we have not escaped the problems being felt throughout Australia, and indeed in most Western economies- problems such as pressures on interest rates, pressures on inflation and a loss of competitiveness in our overseas markets-I believe that we in the Northern Territory have fared better than has the rest of the country. The international slump in commodity prices has squeezed our resource ventures but the exploration and development of our minerals is still surging ahead.

Our economy in the Northern Territory is steadily gaining in strength as it diversifies into new ventures. The tourist industry is looking to beat its recent record growth rate again in the coming year. The heads of agreement for the $100m Yulara tourist village have been signed and work on the complex will begin soon. Last year saw the announcement of a new airport terminal for Darwin- a move which has occurred not before its time. New tourist accommodation was completed in Tennant Creek, Katherine and Alice Springs. New international hotel developments will create a total of 500 rooms in Darwin before 1984, while in Alice Springs a further 600 rooms will be finished by mid-1983.

Last year, 1981, was a year of mixed blessings for our mining industry. The slump in prices of commodities on the world market forced three or our major mining ventures to cut back on production; namely, those at Gove, Tennant Creek and Groote Eylandt. This, along with industrial trouble, notably at Gove, proved to be a blow to our economy and, as a consequence, decreased the amount of revenue that could be collected by the Northern Territory Government in the form of royalties.

On the other hand it is pleasing to report some developments in the mining industry which give cause for hope. This year has great potential for our uranium deposits. The town of Jabiru is established as the centre of the uranium province. The Australian Council of Trade Unions has lifted its ban on loading yellowcake at the Darwin wharf, thus removing a serious impediment to that industry. Recent media reports suggest successful negotiations are being carried out between the Northern Land Council and both Pancontinental Mining Ltd and Denison Mines over their uranium deposits in the Alligator Rivers Region. Investment in oil exploration in the Territory and off our shores over the next six years is expected to be more than $700m. First signs of oil in the Amadeus Basin and the Joseph Bonaparte Gulf have provided the necessary impetus for continuing exploration. The growth in our economy, the surge of capital projects and the new investment and industry in the Northern Territory have, in the main, been due to the aggressive way the Territory has promoted itself in Australia and overseas since self-government.

To give briefly some perspective to the grants involved in the Bill we are discussing today, and in particular the component of $315m for the Northern Territory, I would like to compare this with other forms of government assistance. The Northern Territory is often branded as a millstone around the nation's neck, as a liability, as an area where Commonwealth money brings no return. There is a contention that the Territory requires a level of support from the rest of Australia that imposes intolerable burdens on the nation. Yet, by comparison with the level of assistance given to manufacturing industry in the southern States the so-called burden of the Northern Territory is very small indeed. The Northern Territory economy has no share at all in the $6,000m tariff protecton subsidy levied on the Australian taxpayer. None of the industries covered by protection are represented in the Northern Territory in any meaningful way.

Moreover, continued high levels of protection actually place Northern Territory industry at a disadvantage. The cost to the Northern Territory economy is estimated at $50m. Not only does high protection raise the cost of goods in our market and penalise Territory consumers but also, by exerting upward pressure on the exchange rate, it reduces the competitiveness of Northern Territory beef and minerals in overseas markets.

I referred earlier to the considerable disadvantage in revenue raising at which the Northern Territory was placed under the new health funding arrangements announced last year. When the new health funding levels were announced in June last year I made my reservations very clear in this House. My concern that the Territory would encounter difficulties in raising sufficient revenue to run its own health system was based on two reasons: Firstly, the Northern Territory Government had inherited the Darwin hospital from the Commonwealth with an expensive cost structure and a high cost of maintenance; and secondly, the Northern Territory has an exceptionally high level of disadvantaged patients; in particular, Aborigines who are unable to pay for health care.

Whilst I agree with the thrust of the Federal Government's health policies I can say only that the Commonwealth has made a serious miscalculation in the amount of revenue it thought the Territory could raise from its hospitals. In fact there are simply not enough paying patients in Territory hospitals to achieve the Commonwealth's estimate of additional revenue. The trends which were evident after three months of operation have, after five months, shown a further decline in bed days, occasions of service and, consequently, revenue. It would now appear that the Northern Territory will face a revenue shortfall of $4.67m in this financial year and even higher losses in 1982-83.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Supporting Parent's Benefit-Waterfront Industrial Disputes-Australian Logging Industry-Forest Conservation-Unemployment-James Yates Pty Ltd

PROCTEXT.PARA: Supporting Parent's Benefit-Waterfront Industrial Disputes-Australian Logging Industry-Forest Conservation-Unemployment-James Yates Pty Ltd

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a number of months honourable members on the Government side of the House have been continually decrying the fact that the Commonwealth Government expends some $450m per annum on the supporting parent's benefit. They have blamed the necessity for this expenditure on everything from family breakdowns to modern advertising. I think many honourable members on the Government side have not taken account of the reasons why many women and men who are supporting their children alone end up going onto the supporting parents benefit. In my view the two reasons are the lack of employment prospects and, more importantly, the lack of secure long day care facilities for the minding of pre-school age children and after school care and before school care for school age children. Unless the Government addresses itself to those two questions, the latter in particular, it will find no way of reducing the number of people who are on the supporting parent's benefit. In 1980 the Government spent only $80m on the provision of child care facilities. It is no wonder there are insufficient long day child care facilities in Australia. Compared with the position in 1976 when there was an allocation of $ 67.3m, the 1980 expenditure represents a net reduction in real terms of over 50 per cent in the Government's commitment to child care. Family day care facilities provide long day care for working parents. It is an area in which I believe the Government has acted despicably by reducing funds.

SPEECH.PARA: In my electorate there are three family day care schemes, two operated by local government authorities-the Marrickville and Canterbury councils-and one community based scheme operated by the Ashfield Infants Home. In New South Wales there are nearly 60 family day care schemes. Forty of that number are operated by local government authorities and about 20 are operated by community based groups. The Government has not increased the family day care schemes subsidy of $7 a child a week since 1977. It is five years since the Government increased the grant that is made under this scheme. In that time, by the Government's own reckoning, inflation and costs have risen by 40 per cent. How are these schemes, which provide a very worthwhile role in our community, supposed to exist when the Government freezes their income? They either go to the wall or they can adopt the view that some honourable members on the Government side suggest-that is, charge up to $80 a week for child care. I put it to the House that shop assistants, men and women on low incomes and supporting children on their own, would find those sorts of costs absolutely unacceptable.

The worst thing about the present Government's policy is that it is forcing the community based family day care schemes to go to the wall. The two local government authorities in my electorate are about $20,000 in debt for their schemes at present but they are willing to shoulder the cost and meet it from general rate revenue. But what happens to the community based organisations when they end up $20,000 in the red? They cannot get an overdraft. They either have to put their fees up or close down. Looking at the approach of the present Government one would think that it is probably looking at closing down some of these schemes. That is bad economics because the scheme that the Canterbury Council runs-it does not cost the Commonwealth Government all that much-caters for 150 children. The scheme that the Marrickville Council runs caters for 175 children. Family day care is the cheapest and the most flexible form of child care for the Commonwealth Government to provide. However, this Government continues to starve these schemes of funds. It is imperative that the Government , when considering the Budget this year, take into account the perilous state of family day care in Australia and that it increase the subsidy. It has not been increased since 1977.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The high incidence of industrial disputes on Australia's waterfront and in our shipping industry is cause for national shame, or it should be. In 1981 these disputes cost Australia almost $1 1/2m a day. When one examines the record for 1981 one discovers that in that year there was not a single day which was completely free of disputes affecting some aspect of Australian shipping-on the waterfront, at sea or in transporting goods to the waterfront. That is a disgraceful record. The year was capped by the decision of the world's largest strike insurer to increase charges for existing associates' shipping through Australian ports to three times the world average, and that insurer refused to cover any new members. This is a humiliation for all Australians. The Republic of Korea, our fourth biggest beef market, is deeply concerned about our inability to deliver our meat on time. Concern has been expressed by a number of countries which rely on our coal and our mineral products about our unreliability as a supplier.
—Japan.

—Yes, Japan has expressed that concern on a number of scores, including coal, iron ore and wool in particular. But it is not merely our exporters who are being damaged. Local processors and manufacturers are also being affected. Many local enterprises are dependent on imported materials and components for their businesses. I have been contacted by a number of manufacturing concerns in my own electorate when these troubles have arisen. They have said to me that if the goods are not cleared from the docks within a matter of days they will have to close down their production lines or part of their plants. Without the supplies being efficiently transported, unloaded and delivered, their production lines grind to a halt and they cannot continue to employ people. Australian employees should be deeply concerned about that sort of activity. In the end Australian consumers must meet the costs of delays, storage costs and the need for importers to obtain further finance to maintain stocks held up in ships or on the wharves. Australian consumers should be outraged at having to pay for these extra costs.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned earlier, 1981 did not have one day completely free of disputes affecting at least some sector of shipping. Many of these disputes probably could have been resolved without the need for a stoppage. Some arose because of petty demarcation disputes between the many unions involved on the waterfront. Money alone certainly cannot be the reason for this disgraceful industrial record because many of the strikes had nothing to do with money. Since container shipping was introduced in 1969 a typical change in the average weekly earnings of waterfront union members is from about 3 per cent above the all industries average to 33 per cent above the all industries average. Unless the unions and employers make a real effort to improve the industrial record, export income and jobs will be lost to Australia.

A summary of significant industrial disputes disrupting sea transport in 1981 was issued by the Department of Transport in January this year. It makes instructive, if rather depressing, reading. I think that all honourable members ought to obtain a copy of that document. It lists a number of the disputes which occurred on our wharves and in our shipping industry and comments on the causes and the impact of the disputes. Let me give a few examples of those that were not concerned with money. A large proportion of them were concerned with such things as employment practices, the selection of apprentices, and so on. One dispute involved Seatainer Terminals Ltd at West Swanston, Melbourne. There were stoppages and pickets after men were dismissed by the company for refusing to work with apprentices selected by the employer. The cause of the dispute related to the selection of apprentices. The union demanded the employment of apprentices approved by them, in some cases relatives. Approximately $60m worth of cargo was held up and ships by-passed the port because of the dispute. The men were reinstated after agreement between Seatainer and the unions. Again in Melbourne, one dispute involved a ban on the handling of rail freight following objections by the Waterside Workers Federation to the Victorian Government's adoption of the Lonie report on rail services. That was a political issue in Victoria, a matter of Government policy on which all electors can have their opinions, and about which they are free to agitate and to engage in political activity. But here was a union on the waterfront bringing about a dispute because of that Government's action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a continent which, prior to the advent of the white man, was covered with huge tracts of virgin forest, the Australian logging industry is depleting our forests in a rapacious and criminal fashion. In Tasmania, New South Wales and Queensland the ravages of the saw-millers and wood chippers have left enormous scars on our landscape. In Queensland, with the aid of the Forestry Department, the logging industry has destroyed, in 100 years, half of the tropical rain-forest which stretches from Ingham to Cooktown. The Forestry Department talks about harvesting trees at a sustainable yield, yet no one in the Department has established, by suitable research, exactly what is a sustainable yield. In consequence, it has set high level of quotas which are completely denuding the rain-forests. This treatment of the rain-forests will eventually result in the degradation to such an extent that the Queensland Forestry Department will elect to clear them in order to plant pine trees or allow the land to be taken up for farming, all in the name of progress. Anyone who journeys to Queensland can see the evidence of the indiscriminate planting of pine forests in what were once areas of great natural beauty. The Department talks about conservation in the rain-forests but conservation is not concomitant with logging operations. Conservation in rain-forests means protection from man- induced change and the euphemistic term 'selective logging' really means partial clearing, which is quite contrary to any accepted conservation methods.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that once the forest canopy has been opened up by selective logging more species grow than ever before. However, the saw-millers fail to point out that the secondary growth is weedy, widespread, short-lived and contributes nothing to the diverse rain-forest ecosystem. The rain-forest area may not decrease in area because of logging activities but it will decrease in biological value. Our rain-forests are not necessarily being subjected to outright destruction but they are suffering a slow deterioration through species lost as a result of logging activities. A particular problem is that not sufficient research is being undertaken into the long term effects of selective logging in the rich environment of our rain-forests. Rain-forests are so rich in species that only a few individuals of one species occur in one hectare. Logging , even in small numbers, therefore causes a great reduction in the number of individuals as a percentage of the species population. The reductions affect the balance of nature for both trees and the animals which depend on them. The consequence is that, while some species will prosper, others will fall below the threshold number for survival, which could mean the extinction of the species.

Another example of the despoiling of forests is the attempt by the wood chipping industry to open up the Otway Ranges for wood chipping. The wood chippers promised to be careful in their operations and promised to preserve the forests. But, as I mentioned before, the desecrated areas in Queensland, New South Wales and Tasmania make it clear that they cannot keep their promises. The Liberal State Government has a lot to answer for when it agreed to establish a wood chip mill and ship loading facilities to harvest wood chips from the Otways . Under pressure from conservationists and local residents who appreciate the value of this beautiful area of Victoria, the Government has now agreed to an environmental effects statement. However, the Government has also agreed that existing saw-logging contractors can continue their operations. This decision is appalling and is certain to be another reason why the Liberal State Government will be defeated at the polls on 3 April. Forests all over Australia are being destroyed in the name of progress and private enterprise. These forests are a valuable heritage of the Australian people and should not be destroyed. It is time that the Federal Government took a lead and called on State governments to cease their destruction of our great forests.

The question is not whether wood chipping will have an effect on forest ecosystems but how damaging that effect will be. The problem is that we just do not know the answer because we need the results of long term research studies. What is needed is a national plan to halt and reverse the present decline in the number of trees in Australia. The need is urgent and the Federal Government should act now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last sitting week the honourable member for Wills ( Mr Hawke) fought a battle royal to present a motion to the Parliament on unemployment. Considering the great efforts of that member to be heard, I could only presume that he had proposals of great moment and consequently I hurried to the House to be enlightened. To say that I was disappointed would be an understatement. He commenced by telling us about unemployment and on that we concede his expertise. He and his affiliates of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, ably assisted by the Whitlam Government, were the authors of unemployment in Australia. I waited for him to give a solution to today's problems. He eventually got to that point. He commenced by speaking about job creation schemes. By that, he meant government-structured job creation schemes. As Hansard records, I interjected, in amazement: 'Like the RED scheme'. I say that I interjected in amazement because to me the Regional Employment Development scheme became the cross too big for the faltering Whitlam Government to bear. I thought that the Opposition would like to see it buried. But no, the member for Wills went on to defend that very scheme. In fact he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Hoping that my remarks may permeate even some thick minds, I say this: The evaluation of the RED scheme conducted not by the Australian Labor Party but by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations under this Government in 1977 concluded that when viewed in a broad social and economic framework the scheme's benefits outweighed its costs.
I dispute also the findings of that committee. The Regional Employment Development scheme was commenced on 10 September 1974 as, and I quote from a document relating to it:

a manpower measure having as its objectives the improvement of employment opportunities in areas of excessively high unemployment by encouraging local initiative in these areas to develop suitable work programmes. . . . At least 50 per cent of all approved grants to projects had to go toward the cost of employing people who were currently registered as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service.

In 1974, while the member for Wills was busy starting strikes and, when convinced they were nearly over, apparently assisting to resolve them, I was in local government exercising my brain to attract--

—The honourable member for Wills could not even stay for a whole speech the other day. He had to go at tea time. That afternoon a group of proud councillors went to inspect the first day's production. Then we learnt our first lesson. Unemployed people could not build footpaths, even with the supervision we provided. The job was a tragedy. The men with the ability to do the work already had jobs. Good local government people do not get deterred by things like that. Arrangements were made and seasonal workers or building tradesmen were encouraged to register as unemployed when gaps appeared in their itineraries. Before long, we had an efficient work force. Of course, the labour requirement still reduced substantially the amount of footpaths we could produce but we saw them as something for nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: All that the RED money succeeded in doing was to take men off the regular labour market. In my district, employers of seasonal labour complained bitterly over the lack of their regular labour pool and the dole queue regained its original size. How better to prove this than to look at the registered unemployed during the period of the scheme. During the life of the RED scheme from 1974 to 1976, they grew Australia-wide from 105,800 to 236,800. This was not an isolated situation. My position on the executive of the Country Shire Councils Association of Western Australia gave me contact with all of the State' s local authorities. Everywhere I went the story, with variations, was the same. All work completed was of such poor quality that it had to be redone by skilled labour. We spent $183m of taxpayers' funds on low priority public requirements, often with very shoddy workmanship. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his statement in the House yesterday said:

SPEECH.PARA: Their goal, which we all share has been the higher living standards for Australia's families.

I would like to comment on this because evidently some of the Prime Minister's back benchers have not heard of this new-found concern for families. Their calls for cuts in supporting parent's benefits and the means testing of family allowances, as detailed in the Australian on Thursday, 18 February, have caused a great deal of concern, particularly to the Brotherhood of St Laurence which in its social issues news statement of 18 February had this to say:

'Liberal backbenchers calls for cuts in supporting parent's benefits and for the means testing of family allowances were ill-informed and if heeded, could jeopardise the security of families, and the welfare of children in this country ' the Executive Director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, Rev. Canon Peter Hollingworth said today. He went on to say that there is a danger that the suggestions would reinforce the current anti-family direction of Government policy.

I have spoken before in this House on the evident anti-family direction that this Government's policy has been taking. I point out that over the past five years Government policies have progressively disadvantaged families by failing to increase family allowances in line with inflation and to index the rent and children's allowance components of supporting parents benefits and pensions. There has been a strong transfer of resources away from families, with the result that many are now being pushed into poverty. It makes short work of the Prime Minister's statement today that the Government is looking for higher living standards for all Australians. Evidently it just means some Australians.

Reverend Hollingworth points out that 72 per cent of supporting parent beneficiaries have no other income than the benefit-$69 a week plus $10 for each child and various supplementary benefits. Only 7 per cent of such beneficiaries earn more than $2,548 a year. Only 12 per cent of supporting mothers, and 32 per cent of supporting fathers, own their own homes. The Social Welfare Policy Secretariat report on poverty measurement revealed that 52 per cent of single parent families have incomes below $6,000 per annum.

If Government back benchers are complaining about the rise in the cost of the supporting parents benefit since it was introduced, they should have a good look at some of the causes, because some are directly attributable to Government's policies. For example, rising unemployment causes stress and breakdown in families and makes it very difficult for supporting parents.

Other factors in the rise are inflation, the extension of benefits to supporting fathers in 1977- we welcomed that-and the tendency for some divorced and deserted mothers to apply for supporting parent benefits rather than the widows pension to which they were entitled. Canon Hollingworth pointed out that cuts in supporting parent benefits would lead to increased costs in other areas which, in turn, would certainly lower the standards of living of some Australians. He was referring to mental health care, emergency relief, institutional child care and, in the long term, juvenile crime. The cost of keeping a child in an institution in Victoria is now estimated to be up to $350 a week. That does not take into account the cost of the despair and unhappiness which taking such a step creates in a family. The number of children in institutions has declined steadily since the introduction of the supporting parent's benefit. The number of children admitted to State wardship in Victoria declined from 1,055 in 1975-76 to 680 in 1979-80. That really is of great benefit to families.
Canon Hollingworth concluded:

The proper and humane government response to these problems should not be further harassment and crackdowns but the raising of supporting parents' benefits and pensions and the relaxing of income tests so that parents can bring up children with a decent standard of living.

Also, according to an article in the Australian of 19 February, Ms Philippa Smith, the policy analyst for the influential Australian Council of Social Service, said that reducing welfare payments to single supporting parents would make it impossible for many of them to keep their children. She went on to say that most received pensions because they could not find work and were already living in quite desperate poverty. She added:
A lone parent pensioner with two children gets $104.20 a week at the moment, including the family allowance. This is $19.40 a week below the poverty line.
The report continues:
Miss Smith said federal MPs should consider the children dependent on single parents before they made welfare cutbacks.
'It's not only the parents that they're punishing, it's the children', she said .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a time of concern for the problems of small business I believe that the House should be made aware of a remarkable case of official mismanagement which has resulted in the denial of just compensation to a small business and forced it into receivership and considerable loss. It is a story lasting several years.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1973 the firm, James Yates Pty Ltd, a producer of kid leather, was badly affected by the 25 per cent tariff cuts of that year. It had been a viable operation for over 80 years, but as a result of the tariff cuts it could no longer continue profitably to produce kid leather. The then government offered assistance under the Structural Adjustment Assistance Scheme to firms adversely affected by its tariff policies, so the company applied for a loan to enable it to diversify its production and so remain in business. It found that such loans were not available, that the only assistance it could apply for was compensation for closure. This compensation was offered on the condition that the firm close and suffer loss on certain assets nominated under the Scheme, such closure and loss being traceable to government tariff policies.

On 25 November 1974 the then Minister for Manufacturing Industry wrote to the chairman of the company and said that probably, in his opinion, the company would be eligible for compensation because it appeared to meet the closure and loss tests. However, nearly three months after closure, in March 1976, the company was advised by the incoming Minister for Industry and Commerce that it was not deemed eligible for closure compensation although it had met the closure and loss tests. The company, having got nowhere by making further representations, appealed to the Ombudsman, who advised:

In respect of Ministers' consideration in 1976 and later years of the company's application for closure compensation, I concluded that certain factors that would have been important in making a decision were not included in the Departmental submissions.

The upshot of all this was that in 1980, 4 1/2 years after the company had closed, the Minister agreed that it was indeed, after all, eligible for closure compensation. It might seem that after six years of continual frustration the demands of justice had been met and that, belatedly, the Government had rectified a serious omission. Since the assets involved were worth over $1m the receiver of the company looked forward to the next communication.

However, on 24 September 1980 the receiver was informed that the company would receive only $210,974 as compensation for affected assets independently valued at $1,200,000, or almost $1m less than the loss incurred. This niggardly offer cannot be squared with the principles of the Structural Adjustment Assistance Scheme under which it is offered. It would leave the company's shareholders as unsecured creditors without a cent. It seems, in fact, that the assessment of stock values by the Department of Industry and Commerce disregards the terms stated in the Government's original announcement, which was the basis for the company's request for assistance, as well as the company's situation at the time of closure. Furthermore, the company's building, which has been independently valued at $500,000, was declared to be virtually worthless, as it was 40 years old. On this basis a considerable proportion of the buildings in Australia are therefore valueless-a self-evidently ridiculous proposition.

It is time that this sorry history came to an end. It is surely wrong for a scheme supported by more than one Government and by more than one Parliament to be thwarted by official interference of the kind that I have outlined. It is time to give proper compensation to James Yates Pty Ltd after six years of continual inequity and obstruction. If we are seriously concerned for small business, surely the proper compensation can now be forthcoming, either under the Structural Adjustment Assistance Scheme or by means of a generous ex gratia payment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Review of Commonwealth Functions: Disposal of Commonwealth Book Stores

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

(2) Will the Government reconsider this decision to ensure that the excellent operations of the book stores continue as a desirable public service; if not, when is the decision to be activated.
(3) How many book stores are involved, where are they situated and how many employees are working in each book store.
(4) Is he able to give some definite indication to employees of these book stores who are in a state of concern and have no indication as to when their services will be dispensed with.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Expressions of interest in the leasing of the AGPS book shops have been received from the private sector and are being considered.
(2) The Government intends to proceed with implementation of the decision but at this stage I am unable to say when the new arrangements will come into operation.
(3) There are seven book shops, one located in each capital city except Darwin. The following numbers of staff are currently working in each book shop:
Canberra 5 (plus 1 part-time); Sydney 6; Melbourne 6; Brisbane 4; Adelaide 4; Perth 4; Hobart 2.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Review of Commonwealth Functions: Disposal of Commonwealth Bookstores

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the Report of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions and the recommendation for the disposal of Commonwealth bookstores to private enterprise, has his attention been drawn to reports that employees of those bookstores will be offered to private enterprise tenderers for the bookstores.
(2) If so, have these reports any basis in fact.
(3) If they are factually based, would these employees lose Public Service status.

(4) Have employees in the bookstores been actually or technically precluded from accepting other positions in the Public Service pending decisions on the disposal of the bookstores; if so, is this act discriminatory and unfair to these employees, precluding them from protecting their future in the Public Service and adding to their very real concern for their future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) As the intention is to lease the bookshops as going concerns, prospective lessees will be invited to enter into negotiations with the Commonwealth in relation to terms and conditions of employment with a view to making offers of employment to bookshop staff. However, it will be up to the individual officers concerned to decide whether they wish to accept those offers .
(3) Those officers who elect to remain with the bookshops when they are leased will cease to be employed by the Australian Public Service.

(4) Officers may accept transfers to other Public Service positions but, to ensure adequate service to the public is maintained, some will not take up duty in those positions for the present. Officers promoted will move to their new appointments according to normal procedures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Australia vote for the United Nations Declaration on the Elimination of all forms of Religious Intolerance.
(2) Did the Declaration include the elimination of discrimination by any State, institution, group of persons or person on grounds of not holding any religious beliefs.
(3) Did Australia propose the insertion of a clause guaranteeing freedom from religious belief as well as freedom of religion; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the 36th Session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA 36), Australia co-sponsored Resolution 36/55 by which the draft Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief was adopted without vote.

(3) No, since the question did not arise in these terms in the course of negotiations in relation to the Declaration. Several delegations were, however, insistent on the inclusion of appropriate wording to protect those with atheist views before agreeing to adopt the draft Declaration at UNGA 36. Article One of the draft Declaration thus extends 'the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion' of every person to 'freedom to have a religion or whatever belief of his choice'. The Government therefore considers that the Declaration provides adequate protection for those who hold beliefs of the kind referred to in the question, as well as those who hold religious beliefs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 February, 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How and when did the present governments of (a) Cuba, (b) Guatemala, (c) Chile, (d) Bolivia, (e) Dominican Republic, (f) Panama, (g) Brazil, (h) Paraguay , (j) Haiti, (k) Mexico, (m) Argentina, (n) Uruguay, (o) Honduras, (p) Guyana, ( q) Ecuador, (r) Nicaragua, (s) El Salvador, (t) Columbia, (u) Peru and (v) Costa Rica come to power and what was the nature of the governments they replaced.
(2) Which of the above countries have full civil liberties and regular free elections.
(3) Which of the present governments of these countries does Australia recognise.
(4) With which of these countries does Australia have full diplomatic relations .
(5) What is the basis for Australia's recognition of some South American countries, and not others.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Cuba-President Castro came to power by revolution in 1959 replacing the Batista dictatorship
(b) Guatemala-President Lucas was elected in 1978 for a four year term replacing President Garcia who had been appointed by the armed forces after they overthrew his predecessor
(c) Chile-President Pinochet came to power by a military take-over in 1973 replacing the elected Marxist coalition Government of President Allende
(d) Bolivia-A military junta led by President Torrelio assumed power in September 1981 from the military government of President Garcia Meza
(e) Dominican Republic-President Guzman was elected in 1978 for a four-year term replacing President Balaguer who had been elected President in 1966 and re- elected in 1970 and 1974
(f) Panama-President Royo was elected by the National Asembly in 1978 for a six -year term replacing a military junta which had ruled since 1968
(g) Brazil-President Figueiredo was appointed in 1979 for a five-year term by the military junta which took power in 1964
(h) Paraguay-President Stroessner seized power in 1954, was elected President in 1967 and has been re-elected every five years since then
(j) Haiti-President Jean-Claude Duvalier succeeded his father as President for Life in 1971
(k) Mexico-President Lopez Portillo was elected in 1976 for a six-year term replacing a series of elected Presidents

(m) Argentina-President Galtieri was appointed in December 1981 to head the military junta which has ruled Argentina since 1976 when it staged a coup against President Isabel Peron who had inherited office from her husband
(n) Uruguay-President Alvarez was appointed by a military junta in September 1981 to replace President Mendez. The military junta has been in power since 1976
(o) Honduras-President Suazo Cordoba was elected in January 1982 after eight years of military rule
(p) Guyana-President Forbes Burnham took office under a new Constitution in October 1980 having been Prime Minister since independence in 1966
(q) Ecuador-President Hurtado assumed office on the death of President Roldos in May 1981. President Roldos had been elected in 1979
(r) Nicaragua-The five-man Sandanista regime took power by coup in 1979 from the dictatorship of President Somoza
(s) El Salvador-President Duarte was appointed by a military junta in December 1980. The military junta had seized power in October 1979
(t) Columbia-President Turbay Ayala was elected in 1978 for a four-year term replacing a series of elected Presidents
(u) Peru-President Belaunde was elected in July 1980 replacing a military junta which had ruled since 1968
(v) Costa Rica-President Monge was elected in February 1982 replacing a series of elected Presidents
(2) Assessments differ on the extent of civil liberties and the nature of elections held in the various countries listed. Regular elections are held in the following countries-
Cuba, Dominican Republic, Panama, Paraguay, Mexico, Guyana, Ecuador, Columbia, Costa Rica.
Elections have also been held in Peru (May 1979), Honduras (January 1982) and Guatemala (March 1978) on return to the democratic process from military rule

(3) and (5) Australia recognises all countries of South America and all present governments except that of Bolivia. The Australian Government decided not to recognise the military regime which took power in July 1980 and condemned the reversal of the democratic process in Bolivia
(4)-Guatemala, Chile, Panama, Brazil, Paraguay, Mexico, Argentina, Uruguay, Guyana, Ecuador, Columbia, Peru, Costa Rica.
